en: Mr. Bennet replied that he had not.
vi: Ông Bennet trả lời rằng ông chưa biết.
tr: Mr Bennet duymadığını söyledi.
es: El señor Bennet respondió que no.
vi_translation: Mr. Bennet replied that he did not know yet.
tr_translation: Mr. Bennet said he did not hear.
es_translation: Mr. Bennet replied no.

en: Mr. Bennet made no answer.
vi: Ông Bennet lắng nghe và không trả lời.
tr: Mr Bennet cevap vermedi.
es: El señor Bennet no hizo ademán de contestar.
vi_translation: Mr. Bennet listened and did not reply.
tr_translation: Mr. Bennet did not reply.
es_translation: Mr. Bennet made no move to reply.

en: “I see no occasion for that. You and the girls may go—or you may send them by themselves, which perhaps will be still better; for as you are as handsome as any of them, Mr. Bingley might like you the best of the party.”
vi: - Tôi chẳng thấy có cơ hội nào cả. Bà và mấy đứa có thể đi, hay là để mấy đứa tự đi, như vậy có thể tốt hơn. Vì bà còn đẹp hơn chúng nó, tôi e rằng anh Bingley lại mến bà hơn.
tr: "Bunun için bir sebep yok. Sen kızlarla gidebilirsin, ya da onları kendi başlarına gönderebilirsin, hatta bu belki daha iyi olur, çünkü güzellikte onlardan aşağı kalır yanın olmadığı için Mr Bingley aradan seni seçebilir.
es: ––No veo la razón para ello. Puedes ir tú con las muchachas o mandarlas a ellas solas, que tal vez sea mejor; como tú eres tan guapa como cualquiera de ellas, a lo mejor el señor Bingley te prefiere a ti.
vi_translation: - I don't see any opportunity at all. You and the kids can go, or let the kids go by themselves, that might be better. Because you are more beautiful than them, I'm afraid Mr. Bingley might like you more.
tr_translation: "There is no reason for this. You can go with the girls, or you can send them on their own, in fact, this might be better because since you are not inferior to them in beauty, Mr. Bingley might choose you instead."
es_translation: ––I don't see the reason for it. You can go with the girls or send them alone, which might be better; since you are as pretty as any of them, maybe Mr. Bingley will prefer you.

en: “But, my dear, you must indeed go and see Mr. Bingley when he comes into the neighbourhood.”
vi: - Nhưng mà này, ông đi gặp cậu Bingley ngay khi anh ta đến đây nhé.
tr: "Şekerim, taşındığı zaman gerçekten gidip Mr Bingley'yi görmelisin.
es: ––Bueno, querido, de verdad, tienes que ir a visitar al señor Bingley en cuanto se instale en el vecindario.
vi_translation: - But hey, you should go meet Mr. Bingley as soon as he arrives here.
tr_translation: "Sweetheart, when he moves in, you really must go and see Mr. Bingley."
es_translation: ––Well, dear, really, you have to go visit Mr. Bingley as soon as he settles in the neighborhood.

en: “Mr. Bennet, how can you abuse your own children in such a way? You take delight in vexing me. You have no compassion on my poor nerves.”
vi: - Ông Bennet, làm thế nào mà ông lại có thể sỉ nhục con cái như thế ? Ông cứ trêu cho tôi bực mình để làm vui thôi. Ông không thông cảm cho thần kinh nhạy cảm của tôi tí nào cả!
tr: "Mr Bennet, kendi çocuklarını nasıl böyle aşağılayabiliyorsun? Canımı sıkmaktan zevk alıyorsun. Zavallı sinirlerime hiç acıman yok.
es: ––¡Señor Bennet! ¿Cómo puedes hablar así de tus hijas? Te encanta disgustarme. No tienes compasión de mis pobres nervios.
vi_translation: - Mr. Bennet, how can you humiliate our children like that? You just tease me to get me upset for fun. You have no sympathy for my sensitive nerves at all!
tr_translation: "Mr. Bennet, how can you belittle your own children like this? You take pleasure in vexing me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves."
es_translation: ––Mr. Bennet! How can you speak like that about your daughters? You love to upset me. You have no compassion for my poor nerves.

en: Mr. Bennet was so odd a mixture of quick parts, sarcastic humour, reserve, and caprice, that the experience of three-and-twenty years had been insufficient to make his wife understand his character. Her mind was less difficult to develope. She was a woman of mean understanding, little information, and uncertain temper. When she was discontented, she fancied herself nervous. The business of her life was to get her daughters married: its solace was visiting and news.
vi: Cá tính của ông Bennet là sự pha trộn giữa láu lình, trào phúng châm biếm, dè dặt, và thất thường, đến nỗi mấy chục năm sống chung vẫn không đủ cho bà vợ hiểu nổi ông. Đầu óc của bà giản đơn hơn. Bà có tính cảm thông hẹp hòi, kiến thức nghèo nàn, và tính khí vô chừng. Khi không được như ý, bà tưởng như mình bị lo lắng. Cả đời bà chỉ lo mỗi việc là kiếm chồng cho năm cô con gái. Việc thăm viếng và trao đổi chuyện phiếm là cách khuây khỏa của bà.
tr: Mr Bennet öylesine tuhaf bir hazırcevaplık, ince alaycılık, soğukluk ve bencillik karışımı bir adamdı ki yirmi üç yıllık deneyim karısının onun karakterini anlamasına yetmemişti. Karısının huyunu anlamak daha az zordu. Anlayışı kıt, eğitimi düşük, tepkileri kestirilemez bir kadındı. Mutsuz olduğu zaman sinirleri bozuldu sanırdı. Hayatta bütün derdi kızlarını evlendirmekti; tesellisi ise ziyaretler ve haberlerdi.
es: El señor Bennet era una mezcla tan rara entre ocurrente, sarcástico, reservado y caprichoso, que la experiencia de veintitrés años no habían sido suficientes para que su esposa entendiese su carácter. Sin embargo, el de ella era menos difícil, era una mujer de poca inteligencia, más bien inculta y de temperamento desigual. Su meta en la vida era casar a sus hijas; su consuelo, las visitas y el cotilleo.
vi_translation: Mr. Bennet's personality was a blend of cunning, sarcastic humor, reserve, and unpredictability, so much so that even after decades of living together, his wife still couldn't understand him. Her mind was simpler. She had a narrow-minded empathy, poor knowledge, and an erratic temperament. When things didn't go her way, she felt as if she were anxious. Her whole life revolved around finding husbands for her five daughters. Visiting and exchanging gossip were her ways of relieving boredom.
tr_translation: Mr. Bennet was such a mixture of odd quick-wittedness, subtle sarcasm, coldness, and selfishness that twenty-three years of experience had not been enough for his wife to understand his character. Understanding his wife's temperament was less difficult. She was a woman of limited understanding, low education, and unpredictable reactions. When she was unhappy, she thought her nerves were disturbed. Her whole concern in life was to marry off her daughters; her solace was visits and news.
es_translation: Mr. Bennet was such a rare mixture of witty, sarcastic, reserved, and capricious that twenty-three years of experience had not been enough for his wife to understand his character. However, hers was less difficult; she was a woman of little intelligence, rather uneducated, and of uneven temperament. Her goal in life was to marry off her daughters; her consolation, visits and gossip.

en: “I do not believe Mrs. Long will do any such thing. She has two nieces of her own. She is a selfish, hypocritical woman, and I have no opinion of her.”
vi: - Mẹ không tin bà Long sẽ làm như thế. Bà ta còn hai đứa cháu gái. Bà ta là một con người ích kỉ, đạo đức giả, không tin được.
tr: "Mrs Long'un tanıştıracağını sanmıyorum. Kendi iki yeğeni varken. Bencil, ikiyüzlü bir kadın o, itibar etmem.
es: ––No creo que la señora Long haga semejante cosa. Ella tiene dos sobrinas en quienes pensar; es egoísta e hipócrita y no merece mi confianza.
vi_translation: - Mom doesn't believe Mrs. Long would do such a thing. She still has two granddaughters. She is a selfish, hypocritical, and untrustworthy person.
tr_translation: "I don't think Mrs. Long will introduce him. She has her own two nieces. She's a selfish, hypocritical woman, I don't respect her."
es_translation: ––I don't believe Mrs. Long would do such a thing. She has two nieces to think about; she is selfish and hypocritical and does not deserve my trust.

en: “No more have I,” said Mr. Bennet; “and I am glad to find that you do not depend on her serving you.”
vi: Ông Bennet xen vào - Tôi cũng không tin, nên tôi thấy mừng rằng bà không có ý nhờ vả bà ấy.
tr: "Ben de etmem," dedi Mr Bennet; "hem, onun yardımına ihtiyacınız olmadığını memnuniyetle söyleyebilirim.
es: ––Ni la mía tampoco ––dijo el señor Bennet–– y me alegro de saber que no dependes de sus servicios.
vi_translation: Mr. Bennet interjected - I don't believe it either, so I'm glad you have no intention of asking her for help.
tr_translation: "Nor will I," said Mr. Bennet; "besides, I can gladly say that you do not need his help."
es_translation: ––Nor is mine ––said Mr. Bennet–– and I am glad to know that you do not rely on her services.

en: Mrs. Bennet deigned not to make any reply; but, unable to contain herself, began scolding one of her daughters.
vi: Bà Bennet không màng trả lời, nhưng không thề dằn lòng, bà quay sang mắng các cô con gái.
tr: Mrs Bennet cevap vermeye tenezzül etmedi, ama kendini tutamayıp kızlarından birini azarlamaya başladı.
es: La señora Bennet no se dignó contestar; pero incapaz de contenerse empezó a reprender a una de sus hijas.
vi_translation: Mrs. Bennet did not bother to reply, but unable to contain herself, she turned to scold her daughters.
tr_translation: Mrs. Bennet did not deign to respond, but she couldn't help starting to scold one of her daughters.
es_translation: Mrs. Bennet did not deign to reply; but unable to contain herself, she began to scold one of her daughters.

en: “Then, my dear, you may have the advantage of your friend, and introduce Mr. Bingley to her.”
vi: - Vậy thì bà có lợi thế hơn so với bạn của bà, cứ giới thiệu Mr Bingley với con nhỏ.
tr: "Öyleyse, şekerim, arkadaşının yerini sen al ve Mr Bingley'yi onunla tanıştır.
es: ––Entonces, señora Bennet, puedes tomarle la delantera a tu amiga y presentárselo tú a ella.
vi_translation: - So you have an advantage over your friend, just introduce Mr. Bingley to the girl.
tr_translation: "Then, my dear, take your friend's place and introduce Mr. Bingley to her.""
es_translation: ––Then, Mrs. Bennet, you can get ahead of your friend and introduce him to her yourself.

en: “I honour your circumspection. A fortnight’s acquaintance is certainly very little. One cannot know what a man really is by the end of a fortnight. But if we do not venture, somebody else will; and after all, Mrs. Long and her nieces must stand their chance; and, therefore, as she will think it an act of kindness, if you decline the office, I will take it on myself.”
vi: - Tôi khen bà đã thận trọng. Hai tuần thì có quá ít thời gian để làm quen. Ta không thể biết người mà ta mới quen nghĩ gì chỉ sau có hai tuần, Nhưng nếu ta không bạo dạn, người khác sẽ đánh bạo làm. Dù sao đi nữa bà Long và hai cô cháu cũng muốn thử thời vận. Nếu ta không tiến tới, bà ta sẽ cho rằng ta có ý nhường, bà ta sẽ nắm lấy cơ hội.
tr: "Titizliğine katılıyorum. On beş günlük tanışıklık elbette çok az. İnsan on beş günden önce tanınmaz. Ama biz harekete geçmezsek başkası geçer; kaldı ki, Mrs Long'la yeğenleri de şanslarını deneyecekler; o halde, maksat kibarlık değil mi, sen yardımı reddedersen, bu işi ben üstlenebilirim.
es: ––Celebro tu discreción. Una amistad de quince días es verdaderamente muy poco. En realidad, al cabo de sólo dos semanas no se puede saber muy bien qué clase de hombre es. Pero si no nos arriesgamos nosotros, lo harán otros. Al fin y al cabo, la señora Long y sus sobrinas pueden esperar a que se les presente su oportunidad; pero, no obstante, como creerá que es un acto de delicadeza por su parte el declinar la atención, seré yo el que os lo presente.
vi_translation: - I commend you for being cautious. Two weeks is too little time to get acquainted. We cannot know what someone we just met thinks after only two weeks, but if we are not bold, others will take the initiative. Anyway, Mrs. Long and her two nieces also want to try their luck. If we do not move forward, she will think we are yielding, and she will seize the opportunity.
tr_translation: "I agree with your meticulousness. Fifteen days of acquaintance is certainly very little. A person cannot be known in fifteen days. But if we don't take action, someone else will; besides, Mrs. Long and her nieces will also try their luck; so, isn't the point courtesy? If you refuse the help, I can take on this task."
es_translation: ––I commend your discretion. A friendship of fifteen days is truly very short. In reality, after only two weeks, one cannot really know what kind of man he is. But if we do not take the risk, others will. After all, Mrs. Long and her nieces can wait for their opportunity to present itself; but, nevertheless, as she will believe it to be an act of delicacy on her part to decline the attention, I will be the one to introduce him to you.

en: The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet said only, “Nonsense, nonsense!”
vi: Các cô gái nhìn chằm chằm ông bố. Bà Bennet chỉ nói: - Vô lý, thật vô lý!
tr: Kızlar babalarına baktılar. Mrs Bennet, "Saçmalıyorsun!" dedi sadece.
es: Las muchachas miraron a su padre fijamente. La señora Bennet se limitó a decir: ––¡Tonterías, tonterías!
vi_translation: The girls stared at their father. Mrs. Bennet only said: - Nonsense, absolute nonsense!
tr_translation: The girls looked at their father. Mrs. Bennet simply said, "You are being ridiculous!"
es_translation: The girls stared at their father intently. Mrs. Bennet simply said: ––Nonsense, nonsense!

en: Mary wished to say something very sensible, but knew not how.
vi: Mary muốn nói điều gì đấy hợp lý, nhưng không thể nghĩ ra.
tr: Mary çok anlamlı bir şey söylemek istedi, ama beceremedi.
es: Mary quiso decir algo sensato, pero no supo cómo.
vi_translation: Mary wanted to say something reasonable, but couldn't think of anything.
tr_translation: Mary wanted to say something very meaningful, but she couldn't manage it.
es_translation: Mary wanted to say something sensible, but she didn't know how.

en: The astonishment of the ladies was just what he wished—that of Mrs. Bennet perhaps surpassing the rest; though when the first tumult of joy was over, she began to declare that it was what she had expected all the while.
vi: Sự kinh ngạc của các cô gái chính là điều mà ông mong muốn; riêng bà Bennet còn kinh ngạc hơn cả các cô con gái, tuy nhiên sau những khoảnh khắc xáo động là niềm vui; bà cho rằng đấy là việc bà vẫn hằng mong muốn.
tr: Hanımların şaşkınlığı tam istediği gibiydi; hatta Mrs Bennet'ınki diğerlerini geçti; yine de ilk neşe dalgası durulurken Mrs Bennet bunu baştan beri beklediğini söylemeye başladı.
es: El asombro de las señoras fue precisamente el que él deseaba; quizás el de la señora Bennet sobrepasara al resto; aunque una vez acabado el alboroto que produjo la alegría, declaró que en el fondo era lo que ella siempre había figurado.
vi_translation: The astonishment of the girls was exactly what he desired; Mrs. Bennet herself was even more astonished than her daughters, yet after moments of agitation came joy; she believed that this was what she had always wished for.
tr_translation: The ladies' astonishment was just as he wanted; in fact, Mrs. Bennet's surpassed the others; yet, as the first wave of joy subsided, Mrs. Bennet began to say that she had expected this all along.
es_translation: The astonishment of the ladies was precisely what he desired; perhaps Mrs. Bennet's surpassed the rest; although once the commotion caused by the joy was over, she declared that deep down it was what she had always imagined.

en: “How good it was in you, my dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I should persuade you at last. I was sure you loved your girls too well to neglect such an acquaintance. Well, how pleased I am! And it is such a good joke, too, that you should have gone this morning, and never said a word about it till now.”
vi: - Ông Bennet yêu dấu, ông tốt bụng làm sao! Nhưng tôi biết cuối cùng tôi vẫn phải thuyết phục ông. Tôi biết rõ ông rất thương các con, nên ông không thể bỏ qua mối quen biết như thế này. Thật là tôi vui quá! Kể ra ông đùa như sáng nay cũng hay, ông đi mà không nói một lời nào cho đến tận bây giờ.
tr: "Ne kadar iyisin, sevgili Mr Bennet! Ama seni sonunda ikna edeceğimi biliyordum. Kızlarını böyle bir tanışıklığı ihmal edemeyecek kadar sevdiğinden emindim. Valla nasıl memnun oldum! Ayrıca çok da iyi bir şaka, sen bu sabah git, ama bu saate kadar tek kelime etme.
es: ––¡Mi querido señor Bennet, que bueno eres! Pero sabía que al final te convencería. Estaba segura de que quieres lo bastante a tus hijas como para no descuidar este asunto. ¡Qué contenta estoy! ¡Y qué broma tan graciosa, que hayas ido esta mañana y no nos hayas dicho nada hasta ahora!
vi_translation: - My dear Mr. Bennet, how kind you are! But I know in the end I still have to persuade you. I know very well that you love the children very much, so you cannot overlook such an acquaintance. I'm so happy! It's quite amusing how you joked this morning, going without saying a word until now.
tr_translation: "How good you are, dear Mr. Bennet! But I knew I would eventually convince you. I was sure you loved your daughters too much to neglect such an acquaintance. Oh, how pleased I am! Also, it's such a good joke, you go this morning, but don't say a word until this hour."
es_translation: ––My dear Mr. Bennet, how good you are! But I knew that in the end I would convince you. I was sure that you love your daughters enough not to neglect this matter. How happy I am! And what a funny joke, that you went this morning and didn't tell us anything until now!

en: “But I can assure you,” she added, “that Lizzy does not lose much by not suiting his fancy; for he is a most disagreeable, horrid man, not at all worth pleasing. So high and so conceited, that there was no enduring him! He walked here, and he walked there, fancying himself so very great! Not handsome enough to dance with! I wish you had been there, my dear, to have given him one of your set-downs. I quite detest the man.”
vi: - Nhưng ông yên tâm, Lizzy không mất mát gì khi không hợp với thị hiếu của hắn. Anh ta thuộc hạng người khó thương nhất, một con người đáng kinh tởm, không đáng cho ai lấy lòng. Anh ta chảnh chọe và kiêu kì không ai chịu được. Hắn ta cứ đi lòng vòng đầu này đầu nọ, làm ra vẻ ta đây là nhất! Mà hắn có đẹp trai gì cho cam! Tôi ước gì ông có ở đấy để cho anh ta ít lời răn! Tôi ghét cay ghét đắng anh ta.
tr: "Ama seni temin ederim," diye ekledi, "Lizzy onun zevkine uymamakla pek bir şey kaybetmedi; çünkü son derece sevimsiz, korkunç bir adam, ilgilenmeye değmez. Öyle kendini beğenmiş, öyle burnu havada ki katlanması imkânsız! Ortalarda dolandı durdu, matah bir şeymiş gibi! Dans edecek kadar bile yakışıklı değil! Keşke orada olsaydın da, şekerim, haddini bildirseydin. Adamdan cidden nefret ettim.
es: ––Pero puedo asegurarte ––añadió–– que Lizzy no pierde gran cosa con no ser su tipo, porque es el hombre más desagradable y horrible que existe, y no merece las simpatías de nadie. Es tan estirado y tan engreído que no hay forma de soportarle. No hacía más que pasearse de un lado para otro como un pavo real. Ni siquiera es lo bastante guapo para que merezca la pena bailar con él. Me habría gustado que hubieses estado allí y que le hubieses dado una buena lección. Le detesto.
vi_translation: - But rest assured, Lizzy doesn't lose anything by not fitting his tastes. He belongs to the most unlikable type of people, a disgusting person, not worth anyone's affection. He is so arrogant and haughty that no one can stand him. He just goes around strutting, acting like he's the best! And he's not even handsome! I wish you had been there to give him a piece of your mind! I hate him to the core.
tr_translation: "But I assure you," he added, "Lizzy hasn't lost much by not pleasing him; because he is an extremely unpleasant, terrible man, not worth bothering with. So self-conceited, so arrogant that it's impossible to tolerate him! He wandered around as if he were something special! Not even handsome enough to dance! I wish you had been there, dear, to put him in his place. I truly hated the man."
es_translation: ––But I can assure you ––he added–– that Lizzy doesn't lose much by not being his type, because he is the most unpleasant and horrible man that exists, and he doesn't deserve anyone's sympathy. He is so stiff and so conceited that there is no way to tolerate him. He did nothing but strut from one side to the other like a peacock. He's not even handsome enough to be worth dancing with. I would have liked you to have been there and given him a good lesson. I detest him.

en: “He is also handsome,” replied Elizabeth, “which a young man ought likewise to be if he possibly can. His character is thereby complete.”
vi: Elizabeth đáp: - Anh ấy còn là người đẹp trai nữa, thanh niên là phải như thế. Đúng là mẫu người hoàn hảo.
tr: "Yakışıklı, ayrıca," diye cevapladı Elizabeth, "eh, bir erkek aynı zamanda yakışıklı da olmalı, mümkünse. Demek ki herşeyi dört dörtlük.
es: ––Y también es guapo ––replicó Elizabeth––, lo cual nunca está de más en un joven. De modo que es un hombre completo.
vi_translation: Elizabeth replied: - He is also a handsome man, that's how a young man should be. Truly an ideal person.
tr_translation: "Handsome, as well," replied Elizabeth, "well, a man should also be handsome, if possible. So, he has everything perfectly."
es_translation: ––And he is also handsome ––replied Elizabeth––, which is never a bad thing in a young man. So he is a complete man.

en: “His pride,” said Miss Lucas, “does not offend me so much as pride often does, because there is an excuse for it. One cannot wonder that so very fine a young man, with family, fortune, everything in his favour, should think highly of himself. If I may so express it, he has a right to be proud.”
vi: Cô Lucas nói: - Tính kiêu hãnh của anh ta không làm chị khó chịu, vì có lí do chính đáng nào đấy. Ta không nên thắc mắc tại sao một thanh niên có nhiều thứ như thế: gia tộc cao sang, tài sản kếch xù, lại nghĩ rằng mình cao quý. Nếu chị có thể nói, anh ta có quyền được kiêu hãnh.
tr: "Adamın gururu," dedi Miss Lucas, "beni o kadar rahatsız etmiyor, çünkü bir açıklaması var. Ailesi ve serveti olan, o kadar yakışıklı, herşeyi tamam bir gencin kendine değer vermesinde şaşılacak bir şey yok. Gururlu olmaya hakkı var diyebilirim.
es: ––El orgullo ––dijo la señorita Lucas–– ofende siempre, pero a mí el suyo no me resulta tan ofensivo. Él tiene disculpa. Es natural que un hombre atractivo, con familia, fortuna y todo a su favor tenga un alto concepto de sí mismo. Por decirlo de algún modo, tiene derecho a ser orgulloso.
vi_translation: Ms. Lucas said: - His pride did not bother her, because there was some justifiable reason for it. We should not question why a young man who has so much: a noble family, immense wealth, would think of himself as noble. If she could say, he had the right to be proud.
tr_translation: "The man's pride," said Miss Lucas, "does not bother me so much, because it has an explanation. There is nothing surprising in a young man who has family and wealth, who is so handsome, and who has everything complete, valuing himself. I can say he has the right to be proud."
es_translation: ––Pride ––said Miss Lucas–– always offends, but his pride doesn't seem so offensive to me. He has an excuse. It is natural for an attractive man, with family, fortune, and everything in his favor to have a high opinion of himself. In a way, he has the right to be proud.

en: “Pride,” observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her reflections, “is a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.”
vi: Mary vẫn còn ấm ức trong ý nghĩ kiên định của cô chị: - Em tin rằng kiêu hãnh là một khuyết điểm rất thông thường. Qua những gì em đã đọc, em tin rằng điều này rất phổ biến, bản chất con người hay thiên về tật này. Trong chúng ta rất ít người không có một ý nghĩ tự mãn về mặt này hay mặt khác, hoặc có thật hoặc tưởng tượng. Phù phiếm và kiêu hãnh là hai điều khác nhau, tuy rằng người ta thường xem hai thứ đồng nghĩa với nhau. Một người có thể cảm thấy kiêu hãnh nhưng không tỏ ra phù phiếm. Kiêu hãnh là khi ta có ý kiến về chính mình, phù phiếm là khi ta muốn người khác nghĩ về mình như thế nào.
tr: "Gurur," diye gözlemde bulundu Mary, her zamanki gibi fikirlerinin sağlamlığıyla övünç duyarak, "bence çok yaygın bir kusurdur. Okuduğum onca şeyden sonra şuna inandım ki gerçekten çok yaygın; insan doğası gurura bilhassa eğilimli; o ya da bu gerçek ya da hayali bir özellikten ötürü kendinden memnuniyet duymayan pek az kişi vardır. Gurur ve gösteriş farklı şeyler, ama sık sık aynı anlamda kullanılıyorlar. İnsan gösteriş düşkünü olmadan gururlu olabilir. Gurur daha çok kendimizle ilgili görüşümüze bağlıdır, gösteriş ise bizim hakkımızda başkalarına ne düşündürtmek istediğimize.
es: ––El orgullo ––observó Mary, que se preciaba mucho de la solidez de sus reflexiones––, es un defecto muy común. Por todo lo que he leído, estoy convencida de que en realidad es muy frecuente que la naturaleza humana sea especialmente propensa a él, hay muy pocos que no abriguen un sentimiento de autosuficiencia por una u otra razón, ya sea real o imaginaria. La vanidad y el orgullo son cosas distintas, aunque muchas veces se usen como sinónimos. El orgullo está relacionado con la opinión que tenemos de nosotros mismos; la vanidad, con lo que quisiéramos que los demás pensaran de nosotros.
vi_translation: Mary was still resentful of her sister's steadfast opinion: - I believe that pride is a very common flaw. From what I have read, I believe that this is very prevalent, human nature tends to lean towards this defect. Among us, very few people do not have a self-satisfied thought in one way or another, whether real or imagined. Vanity and pride are two different things, although people often consider them synonymous. A person can feel pride without being vain. Pride is when we have an opinion of ourselves, vanity is when we want others to think of us in a certain way.
tr_translation: "Pride," Mary observed, taking pride as usual in the firmness of her opinions, "I think is a very common fault. From all the things I have read, I have come to believe that it is indeed very common; human nature is particularly inclined towards pride; there are very few people who do not feel some satisfaction with themselves for one real or imaginary attribute or another. Pride and vanity are different things, but they are often used synonymously. One can be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves, while vanity is what we would have others think of us."
es_translation: ––Pride ––observed Mary, who prided herself greatly on the solidity of her reflections––, is a very common defect. From all that I have read, I am convinced that it is indeed very frequent for human nature to be especially prone to it; there are very few who do not harbor a feeling of self-sufficiency for one reason or another, whether real or imagined. Vanity and pride are different things, although they are often used as synonyms. Pride relates to the opinion we have of ourselves; vanity, to what we would like others to think of us.

en: “You make me laugh, Charlotte; but it is not sound. You know it is not sound, and that you would never act in this way yourself.”
vi: - Chị làm em buồn cười, Charlotte à, nhưng việc chị nói nghe không ổn chút nào. Chị hẳn biết nó không ổn nên em tin là chị chẳng bao giờ hành động thế.
tr: "Beni güldürüyorsun, Charlotte; ama bu akıl kârı değil. Sen kendin bu şekilde davranmazdın.
es: ––Me haces reír, Charlotte; no tiene sentido. Sabes que no tiene sentido; además tú nunca actuarías de esa forma.
vi_translation: - You make me laugh, Charlotte, but what you're saying doesn't sound right at all. You must know it's not right, so I believe you would never act that way.
tr_translation: "You make me laugh, Charlotte; but this is not sensible. You yourself wouldn't behave this way."
es_translation: ––You make me laugh, Charlotte; it doesn't make sense. You know it doesn't make sense; besides, you would never act that way.

en: “What a charming amusement for young people this is, Mr. Darcy! There is nothing like dancing, after all. I consider it as one of the first refinements of polished societies.”
vi: - Anh Darcy, kể ra cũng thật vui cho bọn trẻ! Không có gì hơn khiêu vũ. Tôi cho khiêu vũ là cái thú tinh tế đầu tiên của xã hội tao nhã.
tr: "Gençler için ne cazip bir eğlence bu, Mr Darcy! Dans etmek gibisi yoktur valla. Kibar toplumların ilk inceliklerinden biridir diye düşünürüm.
es: ––¡Qué encantadora diversión para la juventud, señor Darcy! Mirándolo bien, no hay nada como el baile. Lo considero como uno de los mejores refinamientos de las sociedades más distinguidas.
vi_translation: - Mr. Darcy, it is truly delightful for the young ones! There is nothing better than dancing. I consider dancing to be the first refined pleasure of elegant society.
tr_translation: "What an attractive amusement for young people, Mr. Darcy! There's nothing like dancing, really. I consider it one of the first refinements of polite society."
es_translation: ––What a delightful amusement for the youth, Mr. Darcy! When you look at it closely, there is nothing like dancing. I consider it one of the finest refinements of the most distinguished societies.

en: Mr. Darcy bowed.
vi: Darcy chỉ nghiêng người không nói.
tr: Mr Darcy başını salladı.
es: El señor Darcy asintió con la cabeza.
vi_translation: Darcy just leaned over without saying anything.
tr_translation: Mr. Darcy nodded.
es_translation: Mr. Darcy nodded his head.

en: “You excel so much in the dance, Miss Eliza, that it is cruel to deny me the happiness of seeing you; and though this gentleman dislikes the amusement in general, he can have no objection, I am sure, to oblige us for one half hour.”
vi: - Eliza, cô khiêu vũ quá đẹp nên thật là vô tình nếu cô không cho tôi được diễm phúc xem cô trình diễn. Mặc dù vị này không thích tham dự cuộc chơi, tôi chắc rằng anh sẽ không từ chối chiều ý chúng ta trong nửa giờ.
tr: "Dansta harikalar yaratıyorsun, Miss Eliza, bizleri seni seyretme mutluluğundan yoksun bırakman zalimlik; her ne kadar bu beyefendi eğlenceden hoşlanmıyorsa da eminim yarım saat nazımızı çekmeye itirazı olmaz.
es: ––Usted es excelente en el baile, señorita Eliza, y es muy cruel por su parte negarme la satisfacción de verla; y aunque a este caballero no le guste este entretenimiento, estoy seguro de que no tendría inconveniente en complacernos durante media hora.
vi_translation: - Eliza, you dance so beautifully that it would be truly unkind if you did not grant me the pleasure of watching you perform. Although this gentleman does not like to participate in the game, I am sure he will not refuse to indulge us for half an hour.
tr_translation: "You dance wonderfully, Miss Eliza, it is cruelty to deprive us of the pleasure of watching you; although this gentleman does not enjoy entertainment, I am sure he would not object to indulging us for half an hour."
es_translation: ––You are excellent at dancing, Miss Eliza, and it is very cruel of you to deny me the satisfaction of watching you; and although this gentleman does not like this entertainment, I am sure he would not mind indulging us for half an hour.

en: “He is, indeed: but considering the inducement, my dear Miss Eliza, we cannot wonder at his complaisance; for who would object to such a partner?”
vi: - Đúng là vậy nhưng cô Elizabeth thân yêu, xét qua hoàn cảnh xui khiến, sẽ không có gì làm lạ nếu anh sẵn lòng chiều theo ta, vì ai có thể từ chối một người như cô?
tr: "Öyledir tabii; ama sebebin ne olduğuna bakınca, sevgili Miss Eliza, nezaketine şaşmamalı –böyle bir eşe kim itiraz edebilir?
es: ––Lo es, en efecto; pero considerando lo que le induce, querida Eliza, no podemos dudar de su cortesía; porque, ¿quién podría rechazar una pareja tan encantadora?
vi_translation: - It is true, my dear Elizabeth, but given the circumstances, it would not be surprising if he were willing to comply with us, for who could refuse someone like you?
tr_translation: "Of course it is; but when you look at the reason, dear Miss Eliza, you shouldn't be surprised at his kindness –who could object to such a spouse?"
es_translation: ––It is indeed; but considering what induces him, dear Eliza, we cannot doubt his courtesy; because, who could reject such a charming couple?

en: After listening one morning to their effusions on this subject, Mr. Bennet coolly observed,—
vi: Sau khi đã nghe các cô huyên thuyên suốt một buổi sáng, ông Bennet lạnh lùng nhận xét:
tr: Bir sabah bu konudaki hararetli konuşmalarını dinledikten sonra Mr Bennet soğuk bir gözlemde bulundu–
es: Después de oír una mañana el entusiasmo con el que sus hijas hablaban del tema, el señor Bennet observó fríamente:
vi_translation: After listening to the ladies chatter all morning, Mr. Bennet coldly remarked:
tr_translation: One morning, after listening to their heated discussions on the matter, Mr. Bennet made a cold observation–
es_translation: After hearing one morning the enthusiasm with which his daughters spoke about the subject, Mr. Bennet observed coldly:

en: “I am astonished, my dear,” said Mrs. Bennet, “that you should be so ready to think your own children silly. If I wished to think slightingly of anybody’s children, it should not be of my own, however.”
vi: Bà Bennet nói: - Ông à! Tôi ngạc nhiên khi thấy ông nghĩ rằng các con ông ngu xuẩn. Tôi có thể khinh thường con cái của người khác nhưng không thể khinh thường con mình.
tr: "Çok şaşırdım, şekerim," dedi Mrs Bennet, "nasıl kendi çocuklarına aptal demeye bu kadar hazır olabiliyorsun. Başkasının çocuklarını küçümseyecek olsam bile kendi çocuklarıma dokunmam.
es: ––Me deja pasmada, querido ––dijo la señora Bennet––, lo dispuesto que siempre estás a creer que tus hijas son tontas. Si yo despreciase a alguien, sería a las hijas de los demás, no a las mías.
vi_translation: Mrs. Bennet said: - Sir! I am surprised to see that you think your children are foolish. I can despise other people's children, but I cannot despise my own.
tr_translation: "I am very surprised, my dear," said Mrs. Bennet, "how can you be so ready to call your own children stupid. Even if I were to belittle someone else's children, I would not touch my own."
es_translation: ––I am astonished, dear ––said Mrs. Bennet––, at how ready you always are to believe that your daughters are foolish. If I were to look down on anyone, it would be the daughters of others, not my own.

en: “Well, Jane, who is it from? What is it about? What does he say? Well, Jane, make haste and tell us; make haste, my love.”
vi: - Thế nào Jane, thư của ai thế? Anh ta nói gì thế? Jane, đọc nhanh lên và nói cho mọi người nghe, nhanh lên con yêu.
tr: "Hadi Jane, kimdenmiş? Konu ne? Ne diyor? Hadi Jane, çabuk ol, söyle, çabuk ol tatlım.
es: ––Bien, Jane, ¿de quién es?, ¿de qué se trata?, ¿qué dice? Date prisa y dinos, date prisa, cariño.
vi_translation: - So Jane, whose letter is it? What does he say? Jane, read it quickly and tell everyone, hurry up my dear.
tr_translation: "Come on Jane, who is it from? What's it about? What does it say? Come on Jane, hurry up, tell us, hurry up darling."
es_translation: ––Well, Jane, whose is it? What is it about? What does it say? Hurry up and tell us, hurry up, darling.

en: “If you are not so compassionate as to dine to-day with Louisa and me, we shall be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives; for a whole day’s tête-à-tête between two women can never end without a quarrel. Come as soon as you can on the receipt of this. My brother and the gentlemen are to dine with the officers. Yours ever,
vi: “Chị thân mến, Nếu chị không quá bộ đến thăm dự buổi ăn tối nay với Louisa và em, em e rằng chúng ta sẽ trở nên xa cách suốt đời, vì cuộc đối đầu giữa hai phụ nữ thì không thể kết thúc khi có xung đột. Khi nhận thư này xin chị đến ngay nhé. Ông anh em và vài người khác sẽ ăn tối cùng các sĩ quan. Thân ái,
tr: "Bugün merhamet edip akşam yemeğini Louisa ve benimle yemezseniz hayatımız boyunca birbirimizden nefret etme tehlikesi içinde olacağız, çünkü iki kadın bütün gün fiskos yapınca sonunda mutlaka kavga çıkıyor. Bu mektubu alınca çabucak gelin. Kardeşim ve beyler akşam yemeğini subaylarla yiyecekler. –Sizin olan,
es: Si tienes compasión de nosotras, ven a cenar hoy con Louisa y conmigo, si no, estaremos en peligro de odiarnos la una a la otra el resto de nuestras vidas, porque dos mujeres juntas todo el día no pueden acabar sin pelearse. Ven tan pronto como te sea posible, después de recibir esta nota. Mi hermano y los otros señores cenarán con los oficiales. Saludos,
vi_translation: If you do not make the effort to come visit and join us for dinner tonight with Louisa and me, I fear that we will become estranged for life, because a confrontation between two women cannot end when there is conflict. Upon receiving this letter, please come immediately. My brother and a few others will be dining with the officers. Dear,
tr_translation: "If you do not show mercy and join Louisa and me for dinner tonight, we will be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives, because when two women gossip all day, it inevitably ends in a fight. Come quickly upon receiving this letter. My brother and the gentlemen will have dinner with the officers. –Yours,
es_translation: If you have compassion for us, come to dinner today with Louisa and me, otherwise, we will be in danger of hating each other for the rest of our lives, because two women together all day cannot end without fighting. Come as soon as possible after receiving this note. My brother and the other gentlemen will dine with the officers. Regards,

en: “Caroline Bingley.”
vi: Caroline Bingley”
tr: Caroline Bingley.
es: Caroline Bingley
vi_translation: Caroline Bingley
tr_translation: Caroline Bingley."
es_translation: Caroline Bingley

en: “With the officers!” cried Lydia: “I wonder my aunt did not tell us of that.”
vi: Lydia thốt lên: - Với các sĩ quan! Con tự hỏi tại sao dì con không nói với chúng con về việc này.
tr: "Subaylarla!" diye haykırdı Lydia. "Teyzem niye bize bundan bahsetmedi, merak ediyorum.
es: ––¡Con los oficiales! ––exclamó Lydia––. ¡Qué raro que la tía no nos lo haya dicho!
vi_translation: Lydia exclaimed: - For the officers! I wonder why my aunt didn't tell us about this.
tr_translation: "With the officers!" Lydia exclaimed. "I wonder why my aunt didn't tell us about this."
es_translation: ––With the officers! ––exclaimed Lydia––. How strange that Aunt didn't tell us!

en: “Dining out,” said Mrs. Bennet; “that is very unlucky.”
vi: Bà Bennet nói: - Ăn tối nơi nhà họ, thật không may.
tr: "Dışarıda yiyor," dedi Mrs Bennet, "bu büyük şanssızlık.
es: ––¡Cenar fuera! ––dijo la señora Bennet––. ¡Qué mala suerte!
vi_translation: Mrs. Bennet said: - Having dinner at their place, unfortunately.
tr_translation: "He is dining out," said Mrs. Bennet, "this is a great misfortune."
es_translation: ––Dinner out! ––said Mrs. Bennet––. What bad luck!

en: “Can I have the carriage?” said Jane.
vi: Jane hỏi: - Con có thể dùng cỗ xe được không?
tr: "Arabayı alabilir miyim?" dedi Jane.
es: ––¿Puedo llevar el carruaje? ––preguntó Jane.
vi_translation: Jane asked: - Can I use the carriage?
tr_translation: "Can I take the car?" said Jane.
es_translation: ––Can I take the carriage? ––asked Jane.

en: “But if you have got them to-day,” said Elizabeth, “my mother’s purpose will be answered.”
vi: Elizabeth nói: - Nhưng nếu bố có dùng mấy con ngựa hôm nay, mục đích của mẹ sẽ đạt được.
tr: "Ama zaten oradalarsa," dedi Elizabeth, "annemin istediği olmuş olur.
es: ––Si puedes ofrecerlos hoy ––dijo Elizabeth––, los deseos de mi madre se verán cumplidos.
vi_translation: Elizabeth said: - But if you use the horses today, mother's purpose will be achieved.
tr_translation: "But if they are already there," said Elizabeth, "my mother's wish will have come true.""
es_translation: ––If you can offer them today ––said Elizabeth––, my mother's wishes will be fulfilled.

en: “I find myself very unwell this morning, which, I suppose, is to be imputed to my getting wet through yesterday. My kind friends will not hear of my returning home till I am better. They insist also on my seeing Mr. Jones—therefore do not be alarmed if you should hear of his having been to me—and, excepting a sore throat and a headache, there is not much the matter with me.
vi: Chị cảm thấy yếu nhiều vào sáng nay, chị nghĩ có lẽ do bị mưa ướt suốt hôm qua. Những người bạn ở đây nhất định không cho chị về nhà khi chị còn chưa khỏe lại. Họ còn muốn chị gặp ông Jones – vì thế đừng lo lắng khi nghe tin ông đến thăm bệnh cho chị. Ngoài chứng đau họng và nhức đầu, chị không bị gì cả.
tr: Bu sabah kendimi çok hasta hissediyorum, herhalde dün ıslandığım için oldu. İyi kalpli arkadaşlarım iyileşene kadar eve dönmenin sözünü bile ettirmiyorlar. Mr Jones'u görmem konusunda da ısrar ediyorlar –o yüzden bana baktığını duyarsan endişelenme– sadece boğazım şiş, başım ağrıyor, başka pek birşeyim yok.
es: No me encuentro muy bien esta mañana, lo que, supongo, se debe a que ayer llegue calada hasta los huesos. Mis amables amigas no quieren ni oírme hablar de volver a casa hasta que no esté mejor. Insisten en que me vea el señor Jones; por lo tanto, no os alarméis si os enteráis de que ha venido a visitarme. No tengo nada más que dolor de garganta y dolor de cabeza.
vi_translation: I felt much weaker this morning, I think it might be because I got soaked in the rain all day yesterday. The friends here absolutely won't let me go home until I recover. They also want me to meet Mr. Jones – so don't worry when you hear that he's coming to check on me. Besides a sore throat and headache, I don't have anything else.
tr_translation: This morning I feel very sick, probably because I got wet yesterday. My kind-hearted friends are not even mentioning going home until I get better. They are also insisting that I see Mr. Jones –so if you hear that he is looking after me, don't worry– it's just that my throat is swollen, my head hurts, and I don't have much else.
es_translation: I am not feeling very well this morning, which, I suppose, is because I got soaked to the bone yesterday. My kind friends do not want to hear about me going back home until I am better. They insist that I see Mr. Jones; therefore, do not be alarmed if you hear that he has come to visit me. I have nothing more than a sore throat and a headache.

en: “Is this a hint to me, Lizzy,” said her father, “to send for the horses?”
vi: - Lizzy có phải con ngụ ý muốn bố cho phép dùng cỗ xe hay không?
tr: "Bana laf mı işittiriyorsun, Lizzy," dedi babası, "atları çağırtmam için?
es: ––¿Es una indirecta para que mande a buscar los caballos, Lizzy? ––dijo su padre.
vi_translation: - Lizzy, are you implying that you want Dad to allow you to use the carriage?
tr_translation: "Are you trying to make me listen to nonsense, Lizzy," said her father, "so that I can call for the horses?"
es_translation: ––Is that a hint for me to send for the horses, Lizzy? ––said her father.

en: “I admire the activity of your benevolence,” observed Mary, “but every impulse of feeling should be guided by reason; and, in my opinion, exertion should always be in proportion to what is required.”
vi: Mary nói: - Em khâm phục lòng nhân ái của chị, nhưng mọi thôi thúc tình cảm cần được lý trí hướng dẫn. Theo em, chị chỉ nên làm theo mức độ cần thiết.
tr: "İyi kalpliliğindeki bu enerjiye hayranım," diye gözlemledi Mary, "ama her duygusal tepki aklın sınamasına tabi tutulmalıdır; kanımca, gösterilecek tepki duyulan ihtiyaçla orantılı olmalıdır.
es: ––Admiro la actividad de tu benevolencia ––observó Mary––; pero todo impulso del sentimiento debe estar dirigido por la razón, y a mi juicio, el esfuerzo debe ser proporcional a lo que se pretende.
vi_translation: Mary said: - I admire your compassion, but all emotional impulses need to be guided by reason. In my opinion, you should only act to the necessary extent.
tr_translation: "I admire the energy in your kindness," observed Mary, "but every emotional reaction must be subjected to the test of reason; in my opinion, the reaction shown should be proportional to the need felt.""
es_translation: ––I admire the activity of your benevolence ––observed Mary––; but every impulse of feeling must be guided by reason, and in my opinion, the effort must be proportional to what is intended.

en: “I have an excessive regard for Jane Bennet,—she is really a very sweet girl,—and I wish with all my heart she were well settled. But with such a father and mother, and such low connections, I am afraid there is no chance of it.”
vi: - Tôi mến Jane Bennet hết mực, cô ta là người con gái rất dịu dàng, với tất cả lòng chân thành tôi cầu chúc cho cô ấy chóng được yên bề gia thất. Nhưng với ông bố bà mẹ như thế, lại thêm các mối quan hệ xã hội thấp kém, tôi e rằng không có cơ hội cho việc này.
tr: "Jane Bennet'a büyük saygım var, gerçekten çok tatlı bir kız; iyi bir yere gelin gitmesini bütün kalbimle temenni ederim. Ama öyle bir anne babayla, öyle düşük akrabalarla, korkarım pek şansı yok.
es: ––Le tengo gran estima a Jane Bennet, es en verdad una muchacha encantadora, y desearía con todo mi corazón que tuviese mucha suerte. Pero con semejantes padres y con parientes de tan poca clase, me temo que no va a tener muchas oportunidades.
vi_translation: - I am extremely fond of Jane Bennet; she is a very gentle girl, and with all my sincerity, I wish for her to soon settle down. But with such a father and mother, and additionally, low social connections, I fear there is no opportunity for this.
tr_translation: "I have great respect for Jane Bennet, she is indeed a very sweet girl; I wholeheartedly wish for her to marry well. But with such parents, such lowly relatives, I fear she doesn't have much of a chance."
es_translation: ––I hold Jane Bennet in high regard, she is truly a charming girl, and I wish with all my heart that she has much luck. But with such parents and relatives of such low class, I fear she will not have many opportunities.

en: “But it must very materially lessen their chance of marrying men of any consideration in the world,” replied Darcy.
vi: Darcy đáp: - Nhưng họ sẽ có rất ít cơ hội để lấy được một anh chồng có vị thế nào đấy trong xã hội.
tr: "Ama kayda değer erkeklerle evlenme şanslarını epey azaltır," diye cevapladı Darcy.
es: ––Pero les disminuirá las posibilidades de casarse con hombres que figuren algo en el mundo ––respondió Darcy.
vi_translation: Darcy replied: - But they will have very little chance of getting a husband with any significant status in society.
tr_translation: "But it greatly reduces her chances of marrying men of any consideration," answered Darcy.
es_translation: ––But it will lessen their chances of marrying men who are of some standing in the world ––replied Darcy.

en: “In nursing your sister I am sure you have pleasure,” said Bingley; “and I hope it will soon be increased by seeing her quite well.”
vi: - Cô có vui thú khi chăm sóc chị cô, nên chúng tôi hy vọng cô sẽ vui hơn nếu chị cô bình phục. – Bingley nói.
tr: "Ablanıza bakmaktan eminim zevk alıyorsunuz," dedi Bingley; "umarım yakında iyileştiğini görünce daha da zevk alacaksınız.
es: ––Como, por ejemplo, en cuidar a su hermana ––intervino Bingley––, y espero que ese placer aumente cuando la vea completamente repuesta.
vi_translation: - You take pleasure in nursing your sister, so we hope you will have greater pleasure in seeing her recovered. – Bingley said.
tr_translation: "I am sure you take pleasure in looking after your sister," said Bingley; "I hope you will take even more pleasure when you see that she has recovered soon.""
es_translation: ––Like, for example, in taking care of her sister ––Bingley intervened––, and I hope that pleasure increases when she sees her fully recovered.

en: Elizabeth thanked him from her heart, and then walked towards a table where a few books were lying. He immediately offered to fetch her others; all that his library afforded.
vi: Elizabeth thầm cảm ơn anh và đi đến một cái bàn, nơi có đặt vài quyển sách. Anh lập tức ngỏ ý giúp cô tìm những tựa sách khác cò trong phòng sách.
tr: Elizabeth ona yürekten teşekkür etti, sonra üzerinde birkaç kitap duran bir masaya gitti. Bingley hemen ona başka kitaplar da getirmeyi teklif etti –kütüphanesinde ne varsa.
es: Elizabeth se lo agradeció de corazón y se dirigió a una mesa donde había varios libros. Él se ofreció al instante para ir a buscar otros, todos los que hubiese en su biblioteca.
vi_translation: Elizabeth silently thanked him and went to a table where a few books were placed. He immediately offered to help her find other titles still in the library.
tr_translation: Elizabeth thanked him sincerely, then went to a table with a few books on it. Bingley immediately offered to bring her more books – whatever was in his library.
es_translation: Elizabeth thanked him wholeheartedly and went to a table where there were several books. He instantly offered to go fetch others, all the ones he had in his library.

en: “Your list of the common extent of accomplishments,” said Darcy, “has too much truth. The word is applied to many a woman who deserves it no otherwise than by netting a purse or covering a screen; but I am very far from agreeing with you in your estimation of ladies in general. I cannot boast of knowing more than half-a-dozen in the whole range of my acquaintance that are really accomplished.”
vi: Darcy nói: - Danh sách của anh về những tài năng thông thường thì quá đúng. Thế giới này có nhiều phụ nữ chỉ đáng khen ở chỗ đan ví tiền hay giăng màn cửa. Nhưng tôi không đồng ý lắm về cách đánh giá phụ nữ của anh. Trong tất cả những người tôi quen, tôi không thể nói khoác rằng biết hơn nửa tá phụ nữ toàn tài.
tr: "Saydığın hünerlerin yaygın olduğu," dedi Darcy, "çok doğru. Bu kelimeyi dikiş nakış dışında haketmeyen kadınlar için de kullanıyorlar. Ama genel olarak hanımlarla ilgili değerlendirmeni kabul etmekten çok uzağım. Tüm tanıdıklarım içinde gerçekten hünerli olan yarım düzineden fazla hanım tanımış olmakla övünemem.
es: ––Tu lista de lo que abarcan comúnmente esas perfecciones ––dijo Darcy–– tiene mucho de verdad. El adjetivo se aplica a mujeres cuyos conocimientos no son otros que hacer bolsos de malla o forrar biombos. Pero disto mucho de estar de acuerdo contigo en lo que se refiere a tu estimación de las damas en general. De todas las que he conocido, no puedo alardear de conocer más que a una media docena que sean realmente perfectas.
vi_translation: Darcy said: - Your list of common talents is quite accurate. This world has many women who are only commendable for knitting purses or hanging curtains. But I don't quite agree with your way of evaluating women. Among all the people I know, I can't boast of knowing more than half a dozen women who are truly talented.
tr_translation: "The skills you mentioned are indeed common," said Darcy, "very true. This word is also used for women who do not deserve it beyond sewing and embroidery. But I am far from accepting your general assessment of ladies. I cannot boast of having known more than half a dozen truly skilled ladies among all my acquaintances."
es_translation: ––Your list of what those perfections commonly encompass ––said Darcy–– has much truth in it. The adjective is applied to women whose knowledge is no more than making mesh bags or covering screens. But I am far from agreeing with you regarding your estimation of ladies in general. Of all those I have known, I cannot boast of knowing more than half a dozen who are truly perfect.

en: “Nor I, I am sure,” said Miss Bingley.
vi: Cô Bingley nói thêm: - Tôi cũng không, tôi chắc như thế.
tr: "Ben de öyle, eminim," dedi Miss Bingley.
es: ––Ni yo, desde luego ––dijo la señorita Bingley.
vi_translation: Miss Bingley added: - Me neither, I'm sure of it.
tr_translation: "I am sure I feel the same way," said Miss Bingley.
es_translation: ––Nor I, certainly ––said Miss Bingley.

en: “Then,” observed Elizabeth, “you must comprehend a great deal in your idea of an accomplished woman.”
vi: - Thế thì , anh hẳn phải lĩnh hội rất thấu đáo trong ý nghĩa của anh về một người phụ nữ toàn tài. – Elizabeth nhận xét.
tr: "O halde," diye gözlemledi Elizabeth, "hünerli kadın fikriniz çok kapsamlı olmalı.
es: ––Entonces observó Elizabeth–– debe ser que su concepto de la mujer perfecta es muy exigente.
vi_translation: - Then, you must have a very thorough understanding of what it means to be an accomplished woman. – Elizabeth remarked.
tr_translation: "In that case," observed Elizabeth, "your idea of an accomplished woman must be very comprehensive."
es_translation: ––Then observed Elizabeth–– it must be that his concept of the perfect woman is very demanding.

en: “All this she must possess,” added Darcy; “and to all she must yet add something more substantial in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.”
vi: Darcy thêm vào: - Tất cả mọi điều này cô ấy phải có, và phải thêm vào đấy là cái gì khác có thực chất trong việc mở mang kiến thức bằng cách đọc thật nhiều.
tr: "Bütün bunlara sahip olmalı," diye ekledi Darcy, "ve tutkulu bir okumayla bütün bunlara daha elle tutulur bir şeyi eklemeli, aklını geliştirmek.
es: ––Debe poseer todo esto ––agregó Darcy––, y a ello hay que añadir algo más sustancial en el desarrollo de su inteligencia por medio de abundantes lecturas.
vi_translation: Darcy added: - She must have all of these things, and in addition to that, she must have something substantial in the way of expanding her knowledge by reading a lot.
tr_translation: "She must possess all this," added Darcy, "and to all this she must yet add something more substantial, in the improvement of her mind by extensive reading.""
es_translation: ––She must possess all this ––added Darcy––, and to it must be added something more substantial in the development of her intelligence through abundant reading.

en: “Undoubtedly,” replied Darcy, to whom this remark was chiefly addressed, “there is meanness in all the arts which ladies sometimes condescend to employ for captivation. Whatever bears affinity to cunning is despicable.”
vi: Darcy đáp lại cô: - Chắc chăn có một sự kém cỏi trong tất cả các môn nghệ thuật mà các cô thỉnh thoảng sử dụng để thu phục cánh đàn ông. Tất cả những gì liên quan đến khôn vặt đều đáng khinh.
tr: "Kuşkusuz," diye cevapladı Darcy, bu söz esasen ona söylenmişti, "hanımların bazen dikkat çekmek için kullandıkları tüm yöntemlerde bayağılık vardır. Kurnazlığa yakın herşey basitliktir.
es: ––Indudablemente ––respondió Darcy, a quien iba dirigida principalmente esta observación–– hay vileza en todas las artes que las damas a veces se rebajan a emplear para cautivar a los hombres. Todo lo que tenga algo que ver con la astucia es despreciable.
vi_translation: Darcy replied to her: - There is certainly an inadequacy in all the arts that you ladies occasionally use to win over men. Everything related to cunning is contemptible.
tr_translation: "Undoubtedly," replied Darcy, as these words were essentially addressed to him, "there is vulgarity in all the methods that ladies sometimes use to attract attention. Everything close to cunning is simplicity."
es_translation: ––Undoubtedly ––replied Darcy, to whom this observation was mainly directed–– there is baseness in all the arts that ladies sometimes lower themselves to employ to captivate men. Anything that has to do with cunning is despicable.

en: “That is exactly what I should have supposed of you,” said Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth thốt lên: - Chính đấy là điều tôi đoán về anh.
tr: "Ben de sizden bunu beklerdim," dedi Elizabeth.
es: ––Eso es exactamente lo que yo me esperaba de usted ––dijo Elizabeth.
vi_translation: Elizabeth exclaimed: - That is exactly what I guessed about you.
tr_translation: "I would have expected this from you," said Elizabeth.
es_translation: ––That is exactly what I expected from you ––said Elizabeth.

en: “Yes, indeed,” cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by his manner of mentioning a country neighbourhood. “I assure you there is quite as much of that going on in the country as in town.”
vi: Bà Bennet nói, với vẻ phật ý vì anh đã đề cập đến miền quê: - Vâng đúng như thế. Tôi đảm bảo với anh rằng có nhiều việc như thế xảy ra nơi miền quê cũng như trong thành thị.
tr: "Evet, tabii," diye haykırdı Mrs Bennet, taşra muhitinden bahsetme şekline gücenip. "Taşrada da şehirdeki kadar çok olay olduğuna sizi temin ederim.
es: ––Ya lo creo que sí ––exclamó la señora Bennet, ofendida por la manera en la que había hablado de la gente del campo––; le aseguro que eso ocurre lo mismo en el campo que en la ciudad.
vi_translation: Mrs. Bennet said, with a look of displeasure because he had mentioned the countryside: - Yes, that's right. I assure you that many such things happen in the countryside as well as in the city.
tr_translation: "Yes, of course," cried Mrs. Bennet, offended by the way the provincial environment was mentioned. "I assure you that there are as many events in the countryside as there are in the city."
es_translation: ––Of course it does ––exclaimed Mrs. Bennet, offended by the way he had spoken about country folk––; I assure you that it happens the same in the country as in the city.

en: “I cannot see that London has any great advantage over the country, for my part, except the shops and public places. The country is a vast deal pleasanter, is not it, Mr. Bingley?”
vi: - Riêng phần tôi, tôi không thấy London có lợi điểm nào to tát so với miền dân dã, ngoại trừ những cửa hàng và cơ sở công cộng. Miền quê thì dễ chịu hơn nhiều, có phải thế không hở anh Bingley?
tr: "Kendi adıma Londra'nın taşradan üstün olduğunu düşünmüyorum, dükkânları, halka açık yerleri saymazsak. Taşra çok daha sevimli, değil mi, Mr Bingley?
es: ––Por mi parte no creo que Londres tenga ninguna ventaja sobre el campo, a no ser por las tiendas y los lugares públicos. El campo es mucho más agradable. ¿No es así, señor Bingley?
vi_translation: As for me, I don't see any significant advantages that London has over the countryside, except for the shops and public facilities. The countryside is much more pleasant, isn't it, Mr. Bingley?
tr_translation: "For my part, I do not think London is superior to the countryside, except for the shops and public places. The countryside is much more charming, isn't it, Mr. Bingley?"
es_translation: ––For my part, I do not think that London has any advantage over the countryside, except for the shops and public places. The countryside is much more pleasant. Isn't that so, Mr. Bingley?

en: “Ay, that is because you have the right disposition. But that gentleman,” looking at Darcy, “seemed to think the country was nothing at all.”
vi: - Đúng đấy, vì anh có tính khí chừng mực. Nhưng anh bạn đây – bà nhìn qua anh Darcy – dường như nghĩ rằng miền quê không là gì cả.
tr: "Evet –çünkü yaklaşımınız doğru. Ama bu beyefendi," Darcy'ye bakarak, "taşranın önemsiz olduğunu düşünüyor sanki.
es: ––Claro, porque usted tiene muy buen carácter. En cambio ese caballero ––dijo mirando a Darcy –no parece que tenga muy buena opinión del campo.
vi_translation: - That's right, because you have a moderate temperament. But this friend here – she looked over at Mr. Darcy – seems to think that the countryside is nothing at all.
tr_translation: "Yes –because your approach is correct. But this gentleman," looking at Darcy, "seems to think that the countryside is insignificant."
es_translation: ––Of course, because you have a very good disposition. On the other hand, that gentleman ––she said looking at Darcy –does not seem to have a very good opinion of the countryside.

en: “And so ended his affection,” said Elizabeth, impatiently. “There has been many a one, I fancy, overcome in the same way. I wonder who first discovered the efficacy of poetry in driving away love!”
vi: Elizabeth sốt ruột nói: - Thế là chấm dứt niềm yêu thương của anh ấy. Con đoán là có nhiều người cũng vượt qua nỗi buồn theo cùng một cách. Con đã tự hỏi ai đã khám phá ra hiệu lực của thi ca trong việc xua đuổi tình yêu.
tr: "Böylece sevgisini tüketti," dedi Elizabeth, sabırsızca. "Aynı şekilde yenik düşen birçok kişi olmuştur. Şiirin aşkı yok etme yeteneğini ilk kim keşfetti merak ediyorum doğrusu!
es: ––Y así terminó su amor ––dijo Elizabeth con impaciencia––. Creo que ha habido muchos que lo vencieron de la misma forma. Me pregunto quién sería el primero en descubrir la eficacia de la poesía para acabar con el amor.
vi_translation: Elizabeth anxiously said: - So that's the end of his love. I guess many people also get over their sadness in the same way. I've wondered who discovered the power of poetry in dispelling love.
tr_translation: "Thus, he exhausted his love," said Elizabeth, impatiently. "There have been many who have succumbed in the same way. I truly wonder who first discovered the ability of poetry to destroy love!"
es_translation: ––And so ended his love ––said Elizabeth impatiently––. I believe there have been many who overcame it in the same way. I wonder who was the first to discover the efficacy of poetry in ending love.

en: “I have been used to consider poetry as the food of love,” said Darcy.
vi: - Thế mà tôi vẫn nghĩ thi ca là thực phẩm của tình yêu. – Darcy nói.
tr: "Şiiri hep aşkın gıdası olarak düşünürdüm," dedi Darcy.
es: ––Yo siempre he considerado que la poesía es el alimento del amor ––dijo Darcy.
vi_translation: - And yet I still think poetry is the food of love. – Darcy said.
tr_translation: "I always thought of poetry as the nourishment of love," said Darcy.
es_translation: ––I have always considered that poetry is the food of love ––said Darcy.

en: “How delighted Miss Darcy will be to receive such a letter!”
vi: - Hẳn là cô Darcy sẽ rất vui mừng khi nhận được thư của anh.
tr: "Böyle bir mektup almak Miss Darcy'yi ne kadar mutlu edecek!
es: ––¡Qué contenta se pondrá la señorita Darcy cuando reciba esta carta!
vi_translation: - Miss Darcy will surely be very pleased to receive your letter.
tr_translation: "Receiving such a letter will make Miss Darcy so happy!"
es_translation: ––How happy Miss Darcy will be when she receives this letter!

en: “Oh, it is of no consequence. I shall see her in January. But do you always write such charming long letters to her, Mr. Darcy?”
vi: - À! Không sao. Tôi sẽ gặp cô ấy vào tháng giêng. Nhưng anh có thường viết những lá thư dài lôi cuốn như thế không, anh Darcy?
tr: "A, önemli değil. Nasılsa onu Ocak'ta göreceğim. Ama her zaman böyle güzel uzun mektuplar yazar mısınız ona, Mr Darcy?"
es: ––¡Oh!, no tiene importancia. La veré en enero. Pero, ¿siempre le escribe cartas tan largas y encantadoras, señor Darcy?
vi_translation: - Ah! It's okay. I will meet her in January. But do you often write such long and captivating letters, Mr. Darcy?
tr_translation: "Oh, it's not important. Anyway, I will see him in January. But do you always write such nice long letters to him, Mr. Darcy?"
es_translation: ––Oh, it's not important. I will see her in January. But, do you always write such long and charming letters, Mr. Darcy?

en: “Nothing is more deceitful,” said Darcy, “than the appearance of humility. It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an indirect boast.”
vi: - Không có gì dối trá hơn là vẻ khiêm tốn bề ngoài. Thường nó là sự cẩu thả trong việc diễn đạt ý kiến, đôi lúc còn là cách khoe khoang gián tiếp. – Darcy nói.
tr: "Hiçbir şey alçakgönüllü bir görünümden daha yanıltıcı değildir," dedi Darcy. "Sık sık sadece düşünce dikkatsizliği, bazen de dolaylı bir övünmedir.
es: ––Nada es más engañoso ––dijo Darcy–– que la apariencia de humildad. Normalmente no es otra cosa que falta de opinión, y a veces es una forma indirecta de vanagloriarse.
vi_translation: - There is nothing more deceitful than the appearance of humility. Often it is carelessness in expressing opinions, sometimes it is even a way of indirect boasting. – Darcy said.
tr_translation: "Nothing is more deceitful than the appearance of humility," said Darcy. "It is often only carelessness of opinion, and sometimes an indirect boast.""
es_translation: ––Nothing is more deceptive ––said Darcy–– than the appearance of humility. Normally, it is nothing more than a lack of opinion, and sometimes it is an indirect form of boasting.

en: “Upon my word, I cannot exactly explain the matter—Darcy must speak for himself.”
vi: - Tôi không thể giải thích chính xác vấn đề này, tự Darcy cậu ấy phải nói ra thôi. Darcy lên tiếng:
tr: "Valla, o kadarını bilemem; Darcy kendisi söylesin.
es: ––No soy yo, sino Darcy, el que debe explicarlo.
vi_translation: - I can't explain this issue exactly, Darcy himself has to say it. Darcy spoke up:
tr_translation: "Well, I can't say for sure; let Darcy speak for himself.""
es_translation: ––It is not I, but Darcy, who must explain it.

en: “You expect me to account for opinions which you choose to call mine, but which I have never acknowledged. Allowing the case, however, to stand according to your representation, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the friend who is supposed to desire his return to the house, and the delay of his plan, has merely desired it, asked it without offering one argument in favour of its propriety.”
vi: - Cô muốn tôi giải thích ý kiến mà cô gọi là ý kiến của tôi, trong khi tôi vẫn chưa nhận ra đấy là ý của mình. Tuy nhiên, xét theo sự trình bày của cô, cô Bennet thân mến ạ, cô nên nhớ rằng người bạn ấy chỉ muốn anh ấy dời lại kế hoạch của mình, người ấy chỉ mong muốn thế thôi chứ không có ý biện luận về sự đúng mực trong cư xử.
tr: "Benim olduğunu iddia ettiğiniz ama benim söylemediğim görüşleri açıklamamı bekliyorsunuz. Ama meseleyi sizin ortaya koyduğunuz gibi ele alırsak, Miss Bennet, unutmayın ki onun eve dönmesini ve planı ertelemesini arzu eden arkadaşı bunu sadece arzu etmiştir, hiçbir gerekçe sunmadan rica etmiştir.
es: ––Quieres que dé cuenta de unas opiniones que tú me atribuyes, pero que yo nunca he reconocido. Volviendo al caso, debe recordar, señorita Bennet, que el supuesto amigo que desea que se quede y que retrase su plan, simplemente lo desea y se lo pide sin ofrecer ningún argumento.
vi_translation: - You want me to explain the opinion that you call my opinion, while I still haven't realized that it is my own. However, according to your presentation, dear Miss Bennet, you should remember that this friend only wants him to delay his plans, they only wish for that and do not intend to argue about the propriety of the behavior.
tr_translation: "You expect me to explain views that you claim are mine but that I have not expressed." "But if we approach the matter as you have presented it, Miss Bennet, remember that the friend who wished for her to return home and delay the plan merely wished for it, without providing any justification.""
es_translation: ––You want me to account for some opinions that you attribute to me, but that I have never acknowledged. Returning to the case, you must remember, Miss Bennet, that the supposed friend who wishes you to stay and delay your plan, simply desires it and asks it without offering any argument.

en: “I see your design, Bingley,” said his friend. “You dislike an argument, and want to silence this.”
vi: Anh bạn anh nói: - Tôi nhận ra ý đồ của anh, Bingley ạ. Anh ghét biện luận, nên anh muốn dập tắt nó.
tr: "Amacını anlıyorum, Bingley," dedi arkadaşı. "Tartışmadan hoşlanmıyorsun ve bu tartışmayı kesmek istiyorsun.
es: ––Conozco tu sistema, Bingley ––dijo su amigo––. No te gustan las discusiones y quieres acabar ésta.
vi_translation: Your friend said: - I recognize your intention, Bingley. You hate arguing, so you want to quash it.
tr_translation: "I understand your purpose, Bingley," said his friend. "You don't like arguments and you want to end this one."
es_translation: ––I know your system, Bingley ––said his friend––. You don't like arguments and you want to end this one.

en: “Perhaps I do. Arguments are too much like disputes. If you and Miss Bennet will defer yours till I am out of the room, I shall be very thankful; and then you may say whatever you like of me.”
vi: - Có thể như vậy, biện luận cũng như tranh cãi. Nếu anh và cô Bennet hoãn việc biện luận của hai người cho đến khi tôi ra khỏi phòng, tôi sẽ rất biết ơn, rồi sau đấy hai người có thể nói gì về tôi cũng được.
tr: "Belki. Tartışmanın kavgadan farkı yok. Sen ve Miss Bennet tartışmanızı ben odadan çıkana kadar ertelerseniz minnettar kalırım; sonra hakkımda ne isterseniz söyleyebilirsiniz.
es: ––Quizá. Las discusiones se parecen demasiado a las disputas. Si tú y la señorita Bennet posponéis la vuestra para cuando yo no esté en la habitación, estaré muy agradecido; además, así podréis decir todo lo que queráis de mí.
vi_translation: - It could be so, arguing as well as debating. If you and Miss Bennet could postpone your debate until I leave the room, I would be very grateful, and then you can say whatever you want about me.
tr_translation: "Maybe. There is no difference between an argument and a fight. I would be grateful if you and Miss Bennet could postpone your argument until I leave the room; then you can say whatever you want about me."
es_translation: ––Maybe. Discussions are too much like disputes. If you and Miss Bennet postpone yours until I am not in the room, I will be very grateful; besides, that way you can say whatever you want about me.

en: “Do you not feel a great inclination, Miss Bennet, to seize such an opportunity of dancing a reel?”
vi: - Cô Bennet, cô có cảm thấy muốn nhân cơ hội này khiêu vũ một bản không?
tr: "Böyle bir İskoç dansı fırsatını değerlendirmek için büyük bir istek duymuyor musunuz, Miss Bennet?
es: ––¿Le apetecería, señorita Bennet, aprovechar esta oportunidad para bailar un reel?
vi_translation: - Miss Bennet, do you feel like taking this opportunity to dance a piece?
tr_translation: "Don't you feel a great desire to take advantage of such an opportunity for a Scottish dance, Miss Bennet?"
es_translation: ––Would you like to take this opportunity to dance a reel, Miss Bennet?

en: She often tried to provoke Darcy into disliking her guest, by talking of their supposed marriage, and planning his happiness in such an alliance.
vi: Cô thường khích động Darcy xem thường nhữn người khách, bằng cách nói về một hôn lễ giả định, hay trù tính cho hạnh phúc của anh trong mối quan hệ thông gia.
tr: Beklenen evliliklerinden bahsederek, öyle bir beraberliğin Darcy'ye getireceği mutluluğu resmederek sık sık Darcy'yi konuğundan soğuması için kışkırtmaya çalışıyordu.
es: Intentaba provocar a Darcy para que se desilusionase de la joven, hablándole de su supuesto matrimonio con ella y de la felicidad que esa alianza le traería.
vi_translation: She often tried to provoke Darcy to look down on the guests by talking about an imaginary wedding or planning for his happiness in a family connection.
tr_translation: By talking about the expected marriage and depicting the happiness such a union would bring to Darcy, he often tried to provoke Darcy to become disinterested in his guest.
es_translation: He was trying to provoke Darcy into becoming disillusioned with the young woman, by talking to him about his supposed marriage to her and the happiness that such an alliance would bring him.

en: “I did not know that you intended to walk,” said Miss Bingley, in some confusion, lest they had been overheard.
vi: Cô Bingley có vẻ bối rối vì cô e ngại những câu nói vừa rồi bị nghe lỏm. - Tôi không biết hai người cũng đang đi dạo.
tr: "Yürümek niyetinde olduğunuzu bilmiyordum," dedi Miss Bingley, kafası karışmış halde, konuştukları duyulmuş mudur diye.
es: ––No sabía que estabais paseando ––dijo la señorita Bingley un poco confusa al pensar que pudiesen haberles oído.
vi_translation: Miss Bingley seemed uneasy, fearing that her recent remarks had been overheard. - I didn't know you two were also taking a walk.
tr_translation: "I didn't know you intended to walk," said Miss Bingley, confused, wondering if their conversation had been overheard.
es_translation: ––I didn't know you were out walking ––said Miss Bingley, a little confused at the thought that they might have overheard them.

en: “You used us abominably ill,” answered Mrs. Hurst, “running away without telling us that you were coming out.”
vi: Bà Hurst nói: - Hai người xấu quá, lẻn đi ra ngoài mà không cho chúng tôi biết.
tr: "Bizi fena aldattınız," diye cevap verdi Mrs Hurst, "çıkacağınızı söylemeden kaçtınız.
es: ––Os habéis portado muy mal con nosotras ––respondió la señora Hurst–– al no decirnos que ibais a salir.
vi_translation: Mrs. Hurst said: - You two are so sneaky, slipping out without letting us know.
tr_translation: "You deceived us badly," replied Mrs. Hurst, "you ran away without saying you were leaving.""
es_translation: ––You have behaved very badly towards us ––Mrs. Hurst replied–– by not telling us that you were going out.

en: But Elizabeth, who had not the least inclination to remain with them, laughingly answered,—
vi: Nhưng Elizabeth không muốn nhập vào đoàn người, cười đáp:
tr: Ama onlarla kalmak için en ufak bir istek bile duymayan Elizabeth gülerek cevap verdi–
es: Pero Elizabeth, que no tenía la menor intención de continuar con ellos, contestó muy sonriente:
vi_translation: But Elizabeth did not want to join the crowd, she smiled and replied:
tr_translation: Elizabeth, who did not feel the slightest desire to stay with them, replied with a laugh–
es_translation: But Elizabeth, who had no intention whatsoever of continuing with them, replied with a big smile:

en: She then ran gaily off, rejoicing, as she rambled about, in the hope of being at home again in a day or two. Jane was already so much recovered as to intend leaving her room for a couple of hours that evening.
vi: Rồi cô tung tăng chạy đi, lòng phơi phới ngao du, trong niềm hy vọng có thể về nhà trong ít ngày nữa. Jane đã đỡ nhiều, nên cô muốn ra khỏi phòng ngủ tối hôm ấy.
tr: Sonra neşeyle koşarak uzaklaştı, hoplayıp zıplarken bir iki gün içinde evine dönme umudu içinde keyiflenerek. Jane o akşam birkaç saatliğine odasından çıkmaya niyetlenecek kadar iyileşmişti bile.
es: Se fue alegremente regocijándose al pensar, mientras caminaba, que dentro de uno o dos días más estaría en su casa. Jane se encontraba ya tan bien, que aquella misma tarde tenía la intención de salir un par de horas de su cuarto.
vi_translation: Then she skipped away, her heart light and carefree, hoping that she could return home in a few days. Jane had improved a lot, so she wanted to leave the bedroom that night.
tr_translation: Then, she ran away joyfully, hopping and skipping with the hope of returning home within a day or two, feeling cheerful. Jane had already recovered enough that evening to intend to leave her room for a few hours.
es_translation: He left cheerfully rejoicing at the thought, while walking, that in one or two more days he would be home. Jane was already so well that that very afternoon she intended to leave her room for a couple of hours.

en: WHEN the ladies removed after dinner Elizabeth ran up to her sister, and seeing her well guarded from cold, attended her into the drawing-room, where she was welcomed by her two friends with many professions of pleasure; and Elizabeth had never seen them so agreeable as they were during the hour which passed before the gentlemen appeared. Their powers of conversation were considerable. They could describe an entertainment with accuracy, relate an anecdote with humour, and laugh at their acquaintance with spirit.
vi: Sau bữa ăn tối, Elizabeth chạy lên phòng chị mình, chuẩn bị áo ấm cho cô, đưa cô ra phòng khách. Hai phụ nữ chủ nhà đón họ với những lời bày tỏ niềm vui. Trong một giờ trước khi các ông xuất hiện, Elizabeth thấy hai người chưa từng bao giờ dễ chịu như thế. Nghệ thuật ăn nói của họ thật tuyệt. Họ có thể mô tả chuẩn xác một buổi tiệc, hài hước kể lại một mẩu chuyện, và thoải mái cười đùa với bạn bè họ.
tr: Hanımlar yemekten kalktıktan sonra Elizabeth ablasına koştu, soğuktan iyi korunduğunu görünce onu oturma odasına götürdü; iki arkadaşı onu sevinç gösterileriyle karşıladılar; Elizabeth onları beyler gelinceye kadar geçen bir saat boyunca gördüğü denli sevimli görmemişti hiç. Konuşma yetenekleri oldukça gelişmişti. Bir eğlenceyi ayrıntısıyla tarif edebiliyor, bir anektodu mizahla anlatabiliyor ve tanıdıkları kişilere neşeyle gülebiliyorlardı.
es: Cuando las señoras se levantaron de la mesa después de cenar, Elizabeth subió a visitar a su hermana y al ver que estaba bien abrigada la acompañó al salón, donde sus amigas le dieron la bienvenida con grandes demostraciones de contento. Elizabeth nunca las había visto tan amables como en la hora que transcurrió hasta que llegaron los caballeros. Hablaron de todo. Describieron la fiesta con todo detalle, contaron anécdotas con mucha gracia y se burlaron de sus conocidos con humor.
vi_translation: After dinner, Elizabeth ran up to her sister's room, prepared a warm coat for her, and brought her to the living room. The two hostesses welcomed them with expressions of joy. In the hour before the gentlemen appeared, Elizabeth found the two women to be more pleasant than ever. Their conversational skills were truly excellent. They could accurately describe a party, humorously recount a story, and comfortably joke with their friends.
tr_translation: After the ladies got up from the meal, Elizabeth ran to her sister, and seeing that she was well-protected from the cold, took her to the sitting room; her two friends greeted her with displays of joy; Elizabeth had never seen them as charming as they were during the hour before the gentlemen arrived. Their conversational skills were quite advanced. They could describe an event in detail, tell an anecdote with humor, and laugh joyfully at people they knew.
es_translation: When the ladies got up from the table after dinner, Elizabeth went upstairs to visit her sister, and seeing that she was well wrapped up, accompanied her to the drawing room, where her friends welcomed her with great demonstrations of joy. Elizabeth had never seen them so amiable as in the hour that passed until the gentlemen arrived. They talked about everything. They described the party in great detail, told anecdotes with much grace, and made fun of their acquaintances with humor.

en: No one made any reply. She then yawned again, threw aside her book, and cast her eyes round the room in quest of some amusement; when, hearing her brother mentioning a ball to Miss Bennet, she turned suddenly towards him and said,—
vi: Không ai trả lời, cô lại ngáp lần nữa, ném quyển sách qua một bên, đảo mắt nhìn khắp phòng hầu tìm ra cái gì khác vui hơn. Khi cô nghe anh mình đề cập đến một buổi dạ vũ cho Jane, cô quay qua anh:
tr: Kimse cevap vermedi. Sonra tekrar esnedi, kitabını bir kenara bıraktı ve oyalanma arayışı içinde gözlerini odada dolaştırdı; kardeşinin Miss Bennet'a balo sözü ettiğini duyunca ansızın ona dönüp şöyle dedi–
es: Nadie dijo nada. Entonces volvió a bostezar, cerró el libro y paseó la vista alrededor de la habitación buscando en qué ocupar el tiempo; cuando al oír a su hermano mencionarle un baile a la señorita Bennet, se volvió de repente hacia él y dijo:
