es: Es de suponer ––dijo Fitzwilliam––, pero eso aminora muy tristemente el triunfo de mi primo.
vi_translation: Fitzwilliam said: - This is not a forced guess, but it sadly diminishes the glory of my cousin's victory.
tr_translation: "This is not an incorrect assumption," said Fitzwilliam, "but it sadly diminishes the grandeur of my cousin's triumph."
es_translation: It is to be supposed ––said Fitzwilliam––, but that very sadly diminishes my cousin's triumph.

en: “There were some very strong objections against the lady,” were Colonel Fitzwilliam’s words; and these strong objections probably were, her having one uncle who was a country attorney, and another who was in business in London.
vi: “Cô gái bị nhiều chống đối mạnh” là lời của Đại tá Fitzwilliam, và những chống đối mạnh mẽ này có thể là từ ông chú làm luật sư nơi miền quê và từ một ông chú khác tại London.
tr: "Hanıma karşı çok güçlü bazı itirazlar varmış," Albay Fitzwilliam'ın sözleri bunlardı, ve o güçlü itirazlar da herhalde eniştesinin taşrada avukat, dayısının da Londra'da esnaf olmasıydı.
es: El coronel Fitzwilliam había dicho que «había algunas objeciones de peso contra la señorita». Y esas objeciones serían seguramente el tener un tío abogado de pueblo y otro comerciante en Londres...
vi_translation: “The girl faces strong opposition” were the words of Colonel Fitzwilliam, and this strong opposition might come from her uncle who is a lawyer in the countryside and another uncle in London.
tr_translation: "There were some very strong objections against the lady," these were the words of Colonel Fitzwilliam, and those strong objections were probably that her uncle was a country lawyer and her other uncle was a tradesman in London.
es_translation: Colonel Fitzwilliam had said that "there were some serious objections against the young lady." And those objections would surely be having an uncle who was a country lawyer and another who was a merchant in London...

en: Elizabeth disdained the appearance of noticing this civil reflection, but its meaning did not escape, nor was it likely to conciliate her.
vi: Elizabeth khinh miệt vẻ bề ngoài của thói biểu lộ cách phê phán lịch sự này, nhưng cô vẫn nắm bắt thực chất ý nghĩa của nó và không muốn hoà đồng với nó.
tr: Elizabeth bu iyikalpli düşünceye dikkat etmiş görünmeyi kendine yediremedi, ama anlamı da gözünden kaçmadı; zaten onu yatıştırması mümkün değildi.
es: Elizabeth desdeñó aparentar que notaba esa sutil reflexión, pero no se le escapó su significado, y no consiguió conciliarla.
vi_translation: Elizabeth despised the outward appearance of this manner of polite criticism, but she still grasped its essential meaning and did not wish to conform to it.
tr_translation: Elizabeth could not bring herself to appear to have noticed this kind-hearted thought, but its meaning did not escape her; besides, it was impossible to appease her.
es_translation: Elizabeth disdained to appear as if she noticed that subtle reflection, but its meaning did not escape her, and she could not reconcile it.

en: “You take an eager interest in that gentleman’s concerns,” said Darcy, in a less tranquil tone, and with a heightened colour.
vi: Darcy nói với giọng kém hoà nhã, mặt ửng đỏ thêm:
tr: "O beyin meseleleriyle hayli ilgileniyorsunuz," dedi Darcy daha az sakin bir ses tonuyla ve rengi daha da koyulaşarak.
es: ––Se interesa usted muy vivamente por lo que afecta a ese caballero ––dijo Darcy en un tono menos tranquilo y con el rostro enrojecido.
vi_translation: Darcy said in a less amiable tone, his face reddening further:
tr_translation: "You are quite interested in those brain matters," said Darcy in a less calm tone of voice, his color deepening further.
es_translation: ––You are very keenly interested in what affects that gentleman ––said Darcy in a less calm tone, his face flushed.

en: “And of your infliction,” cried Elizabeth, with energy; “You have reduced him to his present state of poverty—comparative poverty. You have withheld the advantages which you must know to have been designed for him. You have deprived the best years of his life of that independence which was no less his due than his desert. You have done all this! and yet you can treat the mention of his misfortunes with contempt and ridicule.”
vi: Elizabeth lớn tiếng: - Và anh đã gây ra. Anh đã khiến anh ấy lâm vào cảnh khốn cùng hiện giờ, khốn cùng theo nghĩa tương đối. Anh đã nắm giữ mọi quyền lợi mà anh phải biết đã được sắp xếp cho anh ấy. Anh đã làm mất những năm tốt đẹp nhất của cuộc đời anh ấy, của cuộc đời tự lập mà lẽ ra anh ấy phải được hưởng. Anh đã làm mọi việc này! Và thêm vào đó, anh còn khinh khi và nhạo báng khi người ta nhắc đến những bất hạnh của anh ấy.
tr: "Sebep de sizsiniz," diye haykırdı Elizabeth heyecanla. "Onu bu yoksulluğa siz ittiniz, nispeten yoksulluğa yani. Onun için ayrıldığını bildiğiniz imkânları ondan esirgediniz. Hayatının en iyi yıllarını, hakettiği o hürriyet şansını elinden aldınız. Bütün bunları siz yaptınız! bir de talihsizliğiyle alay ediyorsunuz.
es: ––¡Por su culpa! ––exclamó Elizabeth con energía––. Usted le redujo a su actual relativa pobreza. Usted le negó el porvenir que, como bien debe saber, estaba destinado para él. En los mejores años de la vida le privó de una independencia a la que no sólo tenía derecho sino que merecía. ¡Hizo todo esto! Y aún es capaz de ridiculizar y burlarse de sus penas...
vi_translation: Elizabeth shouted loudly: - And you caused it. You have driven him into his current state of misery, misery in a relative sense. You have taken hold of all the rights that you should have known were arranged for him. You have taken away the best years of his life, the independent life that he should have enjoyed. You did all these things! And on top of that, you scorn and mock when people mention his misfortunes.
tr_translation: "You are the reason," cried Elizabeth excitedly. "You pushed him into this poverty, relatively speaking, into poverty. You deprived him of the opportunities you knew he left for. You took away the best years of his life, the chance for the freedom he deserved. You did all this! And now you mock his misfortune."
es_translation: ––exclaimed Elizabeth energetically––. You reduced him to his current relative poverty. You denied him the future that, as you well know, was destined for him. In the best years of his life, you deprived him of an independence to which he not only had a right but also deserved. You did all this! And you are still capable of ridiculing and mocking his sorrows...

en: “And this,” cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, “is your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this calculation, are heavy indeed! But, perhaps,” added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, “these offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by reflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence. Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?—to congratulate myself on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?”
vi: Darcy thốt lên, khi anh bước nhanh quanh gian phòng: - Ý nghĩ của cô về tôi là như thế đấy! Cô phán xét về tôi là như thế đấy! Tôi cảm ơn cô đã giải thích tường tận. Theo như cách lý luận ấy, những lỗi lầm của tôi quả thật là nặng! Anh ngừng bước, quay nhìn về phía cô: - Nhưng có lẽ các lỗi này đáng lẽ đã được bỏ qua, nếu tính kiêu hãnh của cô không bị tổn thương vì tôi đã thổ lộ chân tình những đắn đo từ lâu đã ngăn tôi có ý định nghiêm túc. Các cáo buộc cay đắng này đáng lẽ đã được kiềm chế nếu tôi cố gắng thêm để che giấu những đấu tranh trong nội tâm tôi, để làm cho cô tự mãn tin rằng tôi đã bị thúc ép bởi tâm tư không vướng bận, thuần khiết; bởi lý lẽ, bởi hồi tưởng, bởi mọi thứ. Nhưng tôi ghét che giấu bất kỳ việc gì. Và tôi cũng không xấu hổ về các ý tình tôi đã thổ lộ. Các ý tình này là tự nhiên và chính đáng. Cô có thể mong tôi được vui trong vị thế thấp kém khi quan hệ với cô hay sao? Mong tôi tự chúc mừng về hy vọng của những người thân, những người có điều kiện hoàn toàn thấp hơn tôi, hay sao?
tr: "Demek böyle," diye haykırdı Darcy hızlı adımlarla odada yürürken, "demek hakkımda böyle düşünüyorsunuz! Demek beni böyle görüyorsunuz! Böyle etraflıca anlattığınız için teşekkür ederim. Bu hesaba göre hatalarım büyük tabii! Belki," diye ekledi durup ona doğru dönerek, "bu hakaretler görmezden gelinebilirdi, ama uzun zamandır ciddi bir girişimde bulunmamı önleyen endişeleri dürüstçe itiraf ettim diye gururunuz yaralandı. Daha ince bir politikayla mücadelemi saklasaydım, akılla, mantıkla, herşeyle gururunuzu okşayarak sizi tarifsiz, katıksız bir tutkunun esiri olduğuma inandırsaydım bu acı suçlamalar geçiştirilebilirdi. Ama sahteliğin her türünden nefret ederim. Ayrıca anlattığım duygularımdan da utanmıyorum. Doğal ve haklı duygular çünkü. Akrabalarınızın düşük seviyesinden zevk duymamı bekleyebilir misiniz? Hayattaki mevkileri benim o kadar altımda olan hısımlarım olacak diye kendimi tebrik mi edeyim?
es: ––¡Y ésa es –– gritó Darcy mientras se paseaba como una exhalación por el cuarto –– la opinión que tiene usted de mí! ¡Ésta es la estimación en la que me tiene! Le doy las gracias por habérmelo explicado tan abiertamente. Mis faltas, según su cálculo, son verdaderamente enormes. Pero puede ––añadió deteniéndose y volviéndose hacia ella–– que estas ofensas hubiesen sido pasadas por alto si no hubiese herido su orgullo con mi honesta confesión de los reparos que durante largo tiempo me impidieron tomar una resolución. Me habría ahorrado estas amargas acusaciones si hubiese sido más hábil y le hubiese ocultado mi lucha, halagándola al hacerle creer que había dado este paso impulsado por la razón, por la reflexión, por una incondicional y pura inclinación, por lo que sea. Pero aborrezco todo tipo de engaño y no me avergüenzo de los sentimientos que he manifestado, eran naturales y justos. ¿Cómo podía suponer usted que me agradase la inferioridad de su familia y que me congratulase por la perspectiva de tener unos parientes cuya condición están tan por debajo de la mía?
vi_translation: Darcy exclaimed, as he paced quickly around the room: - So that's what you think of me! That's how you judge me! Thank you for explaining it thoroughly. According to that reasoning, my faults are indeed severe! He stopped walking and turned to look at her: - But perhaps these faults would have been overlooked if her pride had not been hurt by my sincere confession of the long-standing hesitations that had prevented me from having serious intentions. These bitter accusations would have been restrained if I had tried harder to conceal the struggles within my soul, to make her complacently believe that I had been driven by unburdened, pure emotions; by reason, by recollection, by everything. But I hate concealing anything. And I am not ashamed of the feelings I have confessed. These feelings are natural and legitimate. Could she expect me to be happy in a lower position in relation to her? To expect me to congratulate myself on the hopes of relatives who are entirely lower in status than I am?
tr_translation: "So, this is it," cried Darcy as he paced the room briskly, "so this is what you think of me! So this is how you see me! Thank you for explaining it so thoroughly. According to this account, my faults are indeed great! Perhaps," he added, turning towards her, "these insults could have been overlooked, but your pride was wounded because I honestly confessed the concerns that have long prevented me from making a serious attempt. If I had concealed my struggle with a finer strategy, flattering your pride with reason, logic, and everything, making you believe I was a captive of an indescribable, pure passion, these bitter accusations might have been dismissed. But I despise every kind of falsehood. Moreover, I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed. Because they are natural and justified feelings. Can you expect me to take pleasure in the low status of your relatives? Should I congratulate myself for having kin whose positions in life are so far below mine?"
es_translation: ––And that is –– shouted Darcy as he paced the room like a whirlwind –– the opinion you have of me! This is the esteem in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it to me so openly. My faults, according to your calculation, are truly enormous. But perhaps ––he added, stopping and turning towards her–– these offenses would have been overlooked if I had not wounded your pride with my honest confession of the reservations that for a long time prevented me from making a decision. I would have spared myself these bitter accusations if I had been more skillful and had hidden my struggle, flattering you by making you believe that I had taken this step driven by reason, by reflection, by an unconditional and pure inclination, by whatever. But I abhor all kinds of deceit and I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed, they were natural and just. How could you suppose that I would be pleased by the inferiority of your family and that I would congratulate myself on the prospect of having relatives whose condition is so far below mine?

en: Elizabeth felt herself growing more angry every moment; yet she tried to the utmost to speak with composure when she said,—
vi: Elizabeth cảm thấy mỗi lúc thêm tức giận, nhưng cô cố gắng hết mức giữ bình tĩnh khi nói:
tr: Elizabeth her an daha da öfkelendiğini hissediyordu; yine de konuşurken kendine hakim olmak için büyük çaba sarfetti:
es: La irritación de Elizabeth crecía a cada instante; aun así intentó con todas sus fuerzas expresarse con mesura cuando dijo:
vi_translation: Elizabeth felt increasingly angry, but she tried her best to remain calm as she said:
tr_translation: Elizabeth felt herself becoming even angrier; nevertheless, she made a great effort to control herself while speaking:
es_translation: Elizabeth's irritation grew with each passing moment; even so, she tried with all her might to speak calmly when she said:

en: “You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that the mode of your declaration affected me in any other way than as it spared me the concern which I might have felt in refusing you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.”
vi: - Anh đã nhầm rồi anh Darcy, nếu anh cho rằng cách thức anh tỏ tình gây ảnh hưởng đến tôi theo bất kỳ chiều hướng nào khác, ngoại trừ một điều là đáng lẽ tôi đã có thể cảm thấy lo lắng cho anh khi tôi khước từ anh, nếu anh có cách cư xử như người lịch thiệp.
tr: "Teklifinizi başka tarzda yapmanız beni etkilerdi sanıyorsanız yanılıyorsunuz, Mr Darcy; daha beyefendice davranmamakla beni sadece reddettiğim için incindi mi diye hakkınızda endişelenmekten kurtarmış oldunuz.
es: ––Se equivoca usted, señor Darcy, si supone que lo que me ha afectado es su forma de declararse; si se figura que me habría evitado el mal rato de rechazarle si se hubiera comportado de modo más caballeroso.
vi_translation: - You were mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you thought that the manner of your proposal would affect me in any way other than one: I might have felt concern for you when I rejected you, had you behaved in a more gentlemanly manner.
tr_translation: "If you think that making your proposal in another manner would have affected me, you are mistaken, Mr. Darcy; by not behaving more gentlemanly, you have only spared me from worrying whether you were hurt because I rejected you."
es_translation: ––You are mistaken, Mr. Darcy, if you suppose that what affected me was your manner of proposing; if you imagine that you would have spared me the unpleasant task of rejecting you had you behaved in a more gentlemanlike manner.

en: But when this subject was succeeded by his account of Mr. Wickham—when she read, with somewhat clearer attention, a relation of events which, if true, must overthrow every cherished opinion of his worth, and which bore so alarming an affinity to his own history of himself—her feelings were yet more acutely painful and more difficult of definition. Astonishment, apprehension, and even horror, oppressed her. She wished to discredit it entirely, repeatedly exclaiming, “This must be false! This cannot be! This must be the grossest falsehood!”—and when she had gone through the whole letter, though scarcely knowing anything of the last page or two, put it hastily away, protesting that she would not regard it, that she would never look in it again.
vi: Nhưng khi anh đề cập chuyện anh Wickham, khi cô đọc với chú tâm hơn, các sự kiện, nếu có thật, hẳn vất bỏ mọi cảm nghĩ tốt của cô về giá trị của anh này. Cảm nghĩ của cô càng trở nên đau đớn và càng khó định nghĩa. Cô vô cùng ngạc nhiên, lo lắng, ngay cả kinh hoàng. Cô muốn bác bỏ tất cả, luôn luôn hét lên: “Việc này không đúng! Không thể như thế được! Đây là điều láo toét!” Và khi cô đã đọc xong lá thư, tuy không nhớ gì về một hai trang cuối, cô vội xếp lá thư lại, nghĩ chắc chắn rằng cô không nên tin nó, rằng cô sẽ không bao giờ đọc lại nó.
tr: Ama bu konunun ardından Mr Wickham'la ilgili açıklaması gelince, eğer doğruysa Mr Wickham'la ilgili her güzel düşüncesini yerle bir etmesi gereken ve onun kendi anlattığı hikâyesine gayet tedirgin edici bir benzerlik gösteren olayların açıklamasını biraz daha berrak bir dikkatle okuyunca, daha da şiddetli ve tarifi daha da zor bir acı duydu. Şaşkınlık, endişe, hatta dehşet içinde kaldı. Hepsine karşı çıkmak istedi, tekrar tekrar haykırdı, "Yalan! Doğru olamaz! Yalanın dikâlâsı!" –mektubu okuyup bitirince, son bir iki sayfadan pek az şey anladıysa da, aceleyle katlayıp kaldırdı, yazılanlara itibar etmeyeceğini, bir daha dönüp bakmayacağını söyleyerek.
es: Pero cuando pasó a lo concerniente a Wickham, leyó ya con mayor atención. Ante aquel relato de los hechos que, de ser auténtico, había de destruir toda su buena opinión del joven, y que guardaba una alarmante afinidad con lo que el mismo Wickham había contado, sus sentimientos fueron aún más penosos y más difíciles de definir; el desconcierto, el recelo e incluso el horror la oprimían. Hubiese querido desmentirlo todo y exclamó repetidas veces: «¡Eso tiene que ser falso, eso no puede ser! ¡Debe de ser el mayor de los embustes!» Acabó de leer la carta, y sin haberse enterado apenas de la última o las dos últimas páginas, la guardó rápidamente y quejándose se dijo que no la volvería a mirar, que no quería saber nada de todo aquello.
vi_translation: But when he mentioned Mr. Wickham, as she read more attentively, the events, if true, would surely dispel all her good feelings about his worth. Her feelings became more painful and harder to define. She was extremely surprised, worried, even horrified. She wanted to reject everything, constantly shouting: "This is not right! It can't be like this! This is nonsense!" And when she had finished reading the letter, though she remembered nothing of the last one or two pages, she hurriedly folded the letter, convinced that she should not believe it, that she would never read it again.
tr_translation: But when the explanation regarding Mr. Wickham followed this subject, if it were true, it should have shattered every good thought she had about Mr. Wickham, and as she read the explanation of events that bore a very disturbing similarity to the story he had told with a bit more clear attention, she felt an even more intense and indescribable pain. She was left in astonishment, anxiety, even horror. She wanted to oppose it all, repeatedly cried out, "Lies! It cannot be true! The utmost of lies!" – when she finished reading the letter, although she understood very little from the last one or two pages, she hastily folded and put it away, saying she would not believe what was written and would not look at it again.
es_translation: But when she came to the part concerning Wickham, she read with greater attention. Faced with that account of events which, if true, would destroy all her good opinion of the young man, and which bore an alarming similarity to what Wickham himself had told her, her feelings became even more distressing and harder to define; confusion, suspicion, and even horror overwhelmed her. She wanted to deny it all and repeatedly exclaimed: "That must be false, it can't be true! It must be the greatest of lies!" She finished reading the letter, and without having taken in the last one or two pages, she quickly put it away, complaining to herself that she would not look at it again, that she did not want to know anything about it.

en: Mr. Collins had a compliment and an allusion to throw in here, which were kindly smiled on by the mother and daughter.
vi: Anh Collins đưa ra ngôn từ ca tụng và thêm một lời bóng gió, khiến cho bà mẹ và cô con gái nở nụ cười hiền dịu.
tr: Mr Collins burada bir iltifat etti, bir de bir imada bulunuverdi ve anneyle kızdan nazik bir gülümseme aldı.
es: Collins tuvo un cumplido y una alusión al asunto, que madre y hija acogieron con una amable sonrisa.
vi_translation: Mr. Collins offered words of praise and added a hint, causing the mother and daughter to smile gently.
tr_translation: Mr. Collins made a compliment here and also hinted at something, receiving a polite smile from both the mother and the daughter.
es_translation: Collins had a compliment and an allusion to the matter, which mother and daughter received with a kind smile.

en: “But if that is the case, you must write to your mother to beg that you may stay a little longer. Mrs. Collins will be very glad of your company, I am sure.”
vi: - Nếu đúng như thế, cô phải lập tức viết thư cho mẹ cô xin bà cho phép cô lưu lại thêm một thời gian. Tôi tin chắc bà Collins sẽ rất vui có cô bầu bạn.
tr: "Ama madem öyle, siz de annenize yazın, izin isteyin biraz daha kalmak için. Mrs Collins kalmanıza çok sevinir bence.
es: ––Si es así, escriba usted a su madre para que le permita quedarse un poco más. Estoy segura de que la señora Collins se alegrará de tenerla a su lado.
vi_translation: - If that's true, you must immediately write a letter to your mother asking her to allow you to stay a little longer. I am sure Mrs. Collins will be very happy to have your company.
tr_translation: "But if that's the case, write to your mother and ask for permission to stay a bit longer. Mrs. Collins would be very happy for you to stay, I think."
es_translation: ––If that is the case, write to your mother to ask her to let you stay a little longer. I'm sure Mrs. Collins will be happy to have you by her side.

en: Words were insufficient for the elevation of his feelings; and he was obliged to walk about the room, while Elizabeth tried to unite civility and truth in a few short sentences.
vi: Ngôn từ không thể nào đủ để nâng cao ý tưởng của anh, nên anh phải đi vòng quanh phòng trong khi Elizabeth cố gắng kết hợp phép lịch sự xã giao và sự thật trong vài câu ngắn.
tr: Duygularının yoğunluğu karşısında kelimeler yetmedi; odada dolaşmak zorunda kaldı; bu sırada Elizabeth kibarlıkla gerçeği birkaç kısa cümle içinde birleştirmeye çalışıyordu.
es: Las palabras eran insuficientes para la elevación de sus sentimientos y se vio obligado a pasearse por la estancia, mientras Elizabeth trataba de combinar la verdad con la cortesía en frases breves.
vi_translation: Words could never suffice to elevate his ideas, so he had to pace around the room while Elizabeth tried to blend politeness and truth into a few short sentences.
tr_translation: Words failed in the face of the intensity of his emotions; he had to pace around the room; meanwhile, Elizabeth was trying to politely condense the truth into a few short sentences.
es_translation: Words were insufficient to express the elevation of his feelings, and he found himself compelled to pace the room, while Elizabeth tried to combine truth with courtesy in brief phrases.

en: Elizabeth made no objection: the door was then allowed to be shut, and the carriage drove off.
vi: Elizabeth đồng ý, rồi cánh cửa đóng lại, chiếc xe chạy đi.
tr: Elizabeth itiraz etmedi; –sonra kapının kapanmasına izin verildi ve araba yola koyuldu.
es: Elizabeth no se opuso; se cerró la portezuela y el carruaje partió.
vi_translation: Elizabeth agreed, then the door closed, and the car drove away.
tr_translation: Elizabeth did not object; –then the door was allowed to close and the carriage set off.
es_translation: Elizabeth did not object; the door closed and the carriage departed.

en: Elizabeth privately added, “And how much I shall have to conceal!”
vi: Trong thâm tâm, Elizabeth thêm: “Và chị sẽ có thêm biết bao nhiêu chuyện phải giấu kín.
tr: "Benim de saklayacak ne çok şeyim var," dedi Elizabeth kendi kendine.
es: ¡Cuánto tengo que contar! Elizabeth añadió para sus adentros: «¡Y yo, cuántas cosas tengo que callarme!»
vi_translation: In her heart, Elizabeth added: "And you will have so many more things to keep secret."
tr_translation: "I also have so many things to hide," said Elizabeth to herself.
es_translation: Elizabeth added to herself: "And I, how many things I have to keep to myself!"

en: “And we mean to treat you all,” added Lydia; “but you must lend us the money, for we have just spent ours at the shop out there.” Then showing her purchases,—“Look here, I have bought this bonnet. I do not think it is very pretty; but I thought I might as well buy it as not. I shall pull it to pieces as soon as I get home, and see if I can make it up any better.”
vi: Các chị có ngạc nhiên thích thú không?” Lydia thêm: - Chúng em đãi các chị đấy, nhưng các chị phải cho chúng em mượn tiền vì chúng em đã tiêu hết tiền ở cửa hiệu đằng kia. Rồi cô cho xem mấy món hàng: - Nhìn đây, em đã mua chiếc mũ này. Em nghĩ nó không đẹp lắm, nhưng thà mua nó còn hơn không. Em sẽ sửa nó khi em về đến nhà, để xem nó có đẹp hơn không.
tr: "Hepinize ziyafet çekmeyi düşünüyoruz," diye ekledi Lydia; "ama bize borç vermelisiniz, çünkü bütün paramızı şu dükkânda harcadık." Sonra aldıklarını gösterdi: "Bakın, bu boneyi aldım. Pek güzel değil, ama iş olsun diye aldım. Eve gidince söküp bakacağım, bir şeye benzetebilir miyim diye.
es: ––Queremos convidaros a todas ––añadió Lydia––; pero tendréis que prestarnos el dinero, porque acabamos de gastar el nuestro en la tienda de ahí fuera. Y, enseñando sus compras, agregó: ––Mirad qué sombrero me he comprado. No creo que sea muy bonito, pero pensé que lo mismo daba comprarlo que no; lo desharé en cuanto lleguemos a casa y veré si puedo mejorarlo algo.
vi_translation: Lydia added. - We will treat you, but you have to lend us money because we spent all our money at the shop over there. Then she showed some items: - Look here, I bought this hat. I think it's not very pretty, but it's better to buy it than not. I'll fix it when I get home, to see if it looks better.
tr_translation: "We are thinking of treating you all to a feast," Lydia added; "but you must lend us some money, because we spent all our money in this shop." Then she showed what she had bought: "Look, I bought this bonnet. It's not very nice, but I bought it just for the sake of it. When I get home, I'll take it apart to see if I can make something out of it."
es_translation: ––We want to invite all of you ––added Lydia––; but you will have to lend us the money, because we just spent ours in the store out there. And, showing her purchases, she added: ––Look at the hat I bought. I don't think it's very pretty, but I thought it was the same to buy it or not; I'll take it apart as soon as we get home and see if I can improve it a bit.

en: “Are they, indeed?” cried Elizabeth, with the greatest satisfaction.
vi: Elizabeth thốt lên, trong hài lòng tột độ: - Họ sẽ đi thật à?
tr: "Gerçekten mi?" diye haykırdı Elizabeth, büyük bir memnuniyetle.
es: ––¿Sí, de veras? ––exclamó Elizabeth satisfechísima.
vi_translation: Elizabeth exclaimed, in utmost satisfaction: - Are they really going to go?
tr_translation: "Really?" cried Elizabeth, with great satisfaction.
es_translation: ––Really? ––exclaimed Elizabeth very satisfied.

en: “Now I have got some news for you,” said Lydia, as they sat down to table. “What do you think? It is excellent news, capital news, and about a certain person that we all like.”
vi: Lydia nói, khi các chị em cùng ngồi xuống bàn ăn: - Bây giờ em có ít tin tức cho các chị. Các chị thử đoán xem! Đây là tin cực kỳ tốt đẹp, tin quan trọng, có quan hệ đến một người mà tất cả chúng ta đều mến.
tr: "Şimdi size haberlerim var," dedi Lydia, masaya otururlarken. "Bilin bakalım! Harika haberler, olağanüstü haberler, hem de hepimizin sevdiği bir kişi hakkında.
es: ––Tengo que daros algunas noticias ––dijo Lydia cuando se sentaron a la mesa—. ¿Qué creéis? Es lo más sensacional que podáis imaginaros; una nueva importantísima acerca de cierta persona que a todas nos gusta.
vi_translation: Lydia said, as the sisters sat down at the dining table: - Now I have some news for you all. Try to guess! This is extremely good news, important news, related to a person we all cherish.
tr_translation: "Now I have news for you," said Lydia, as they sat down at the table. "Guess what! Wonderful news, extraordinary news, and it's about someone we all love."
es_translation: ––I have some news to share with you ––said Lydia as they sat down at the table—. What do you think? It's the most sensational thing you can imagine; something very important about a certain person we all like.

en: “But I hope there is no strong attachment on either side,” said Jane.
vi: Jane nói: - Nhưng chị hy vọng không bên nào còn quyến luyến.
tr: "Ama galiba iki tarafta da güçlü bir bağlılık yok," dedi Jane.
es: ––Pero supongo que no habría mucho amor entre ellos ––dijo Jane.
vi_translation: Jane said: - But she hopes that neither side remains attached.
tr_translation: "But I guess there isn't a strong commitment on either side," said Jane.
es_translation: ––But I suppose there wouldn't be much love between them ––said Jane.

en: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, however incapable of such coarseness of expression herself, the coarseness of the sentiment was little other than her own breast had formerly harboured and fancied liberal!
vi: Elizabeth bị sốc khi nghĩ rằng, dù cô không có khả năng diễn tả thô lỗ như thế, sự thô lỗ trong cảm nghĩ theo cách này không khác nào khi bộ ngực của cô được tự do phơi bày ra!
tr: Elizabeth dondu kaldı, böyle kaba ifadeleri kullanmak elinden gelmese de, bu tür kaba duyguları vaktiyle kendisinin de göğsünde beslemiş ve bunu makul bulmuş olduğunu düşününce!
es: Elizabeth se escandalizó al pensar que, aunque ella fuese incapaz de expresar semejante ordinariez, el sentimiento no era muy distinto del que ella misma había abrigado en otro tiempo y admitido como liberal.
vi_translation: Elizabeth was shocked to think that, although she did not have the ability to express such rudeness, the rudeness in her feelings in this way was no different than if her breasts were freely exposed!
tr_translation: Elizabeth was stunned, and although she could not bring herself to use such coarse expressions, she thought about how she had once harbored such coarse feelings in her own heart and had found them reasonable!
es_translation: Elizabeth was scandalized to think that, although she was incapable of expressing such vulgarity, the sentiment was not very different from what she herself had once harbored and admitted as liberal.

en: To this, Mary very gravely replied, “Far be it from me, my dear sister, to depreciate such pleasures. They would doubtless be congenial with the generality of female minds. But I confess they would have no charms for me. I should infinitely prefer a book.”
vi: Mary trả lời, nghiêm trang: - Chị không hề xem nhẹ những vui thú như thế, rõ ràng hợp với tính khí của phụ nữ. Nhưng thú thật, chị không ham gì những thú này. Nhất định chị thích đọc sách hơn.
tr: Mary buna ciddiyetle cevap verdi, "Aman, benden uzak olsun, hemşirem, böyle zevkler bana göre değil. Çoğu kadın böyle şeyleri sever. Ama benim için hiç cazip değiller. Ben kitap okumayı tercih ederim.
es: Mary replicó gravemente: ––Lejos de mí, querida hermana, está el despreciar esos placeres. Serán propios, sin duda, de la mayoría de las mujeres. Pero confieso que a mí no me hacen ninguna gracia; habría preferido mil veces antes un libro.
vi_translation: Mary replied, solemnly: - She does not underestimate such pleasures, which are clearly in line with the temperament of women. But to be honest, she does not crave these pleasures. She definitely prefers reading books.
tr_translation: Mary answered this seriously, "Oh, keep it away from me, sister, such pleasures are not for me." Most women like such things. But they are not attractive to me at all. I prefer to read books."
es_translation: Mary replied gravely: ––Far be it from me, dear sister, to disdain those pleasures. They are undoubtedly suitable for the majority of women. But I confess that they do not amuse me at all; I would have preferred a book a thousand times over.

en: “Indeed,” replied Elizabeth, “I am heartily sorry for him; but he has other feelings which will probably soon drive away his regard for me. You do not blame me, however, for refusing him?”
vi: Elizabeth trả lời: - Đúng vậy, em thương hại anh ấy, nhưng anh có những suy nghĩ khác có thể sẽ xua tan tình cảm của anh đối với em. Tuy nhiên, chị không trách em đã từ khước anh chứ?
tr: "Tabii," diye cevapladı Elizabeth, "onun için gerçekten üzülüyorum; ama bana olan ilgisini yok edecek başka duyguları da var. Yine de onu reddettiğim için beni suçlamıyorsun, değil mi?
es: ––Es cierto ––repuso Elizabeth––, lo siento de veras por él; pero su orgullo es tan grande que no tardará mucho en olvidarme. ¿Te parece mal que le haya rechazado?
vi_translation: Elizabeth replied: - That's right, I pity him, but you have other thoughts that might dispel your feelings for me. However, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?
tr_translation: "Of course," replied Elizabeth, "I really feel sorry for him; but he has other feelings that will extinguish his interest in me. Still, you don't blame me for rejecting him, do you?"
es_translation: ––It is true ––replied Elizabeth––, I truly feel sorry for him; but his pride is so great that it won't take long for him to forget me. Do you think it was wrong for me to reject him?

en: “I never thought Mr. Darcy so deficient in the appearance of it as you used to do.”
vi: - Chị chưa bao giờ nghĩ anh Darcy lại yếu kém về mặt bề ngoài như em thường nghĩ.
tr: "Mr Darcy'nin görüntüsünde iyilik olmadığını hiç düşünmedim, senin aksine.
es: ––Yo nunca consideré que las apariencias de Darcy eran tan malas como tú decías.
vi_translation: - I never thought Mr. Darcy was as lacking in appearance as you often think.
tr_translation: "I never thought there was any goodness in Mr. Darcy's appearance, unlike you."
es_translation: ––I never considered that Darcy's appearances were as bad as you said.

en: “Indeed, I could not. I was uncomfortable enough, I was very uncomfortable—I may say unhappy. And with no one to speak to of what I felt, no Jane to comfort me, and say that I had not been so very weak, and vain, and nonsensical, as I knew I had! Oh, how I wanted you!”
vi: - Thật ra, lúc ấy em chưa thể suy xét gì cả. Em bị quá xáo trộn. Em bị xáo trộn nhiều, có thể nói em khổ sở. Và không có ai để trao đổi về những gì em nghĩ, không có chị Jane an ủi em và nói rằng em chưa từng yếu đuối, rỗng tuếch và vô lý đến thế! Ôi! Em cần đến chị quá!
tr: "Elbette hayır. Çok rahatsız oldum. Gayet rahatsız, hatta mutsuz oldum diyebilirim. Hissettiklerimi konuşacak kimse de yok, beni rahatlatıp sandığım kadar zayıf, kafasız ve kalpsiz davranmadığımı söyleyecek Jane de yok! Ah! seni nasıl aradım!
es: ––No habría podido, es cierto. Estaba tan molesta, o, mejor dicho, tan triste. Y lo peor de todo era que no tenía a quién confiar mi pesar. ¡No tener a nadie a quien hablar de lo que sentía, ninguna Jane que me consolara y me dijera que no había sido tan frágil, tan vana y tan insensata como yo me creía! ¡Qué falta me hiciste!
vi_translation: - Actually, at that time, I couldn't think about anything. I was too disturbed. I was very disturbed, you could say I was miserable. And there was no one to talk to about what I was thinking, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I had never been so weak, empty, and unreasonable! Oh! I needed you so much!
tr_translation: "Of course not. I am very disturbed. I can say I am quite disturbed, even unhappy. There is no one to talk to about what I feel, no Jane to comfort me and tell me that I am not acting as weak, brainless, and heartless as I think! Oh! how I have missed you!"
es_translation: ––I wouldn't have been able to, it's true. I was so upset, or rather, so sad. And the worst part of all was that I had no one to confide my sorrow in. To have no one to talk to about what I felt, no Jane to console me and tell me that I hadn't been as fragile, as vain, and as foolish as I thought I was! How much I missed you!

en: Miss Bennet paused a little, and then replied, “Surely there can be no occasion for exposing him so dreadfully. What is your own opinion?”
vi: Cô Bennet ngập ngừng một chút, rồi trả lời: - Chắc chắn là không có cơ hội để vạch trần anh ấy một cách kinh khiếp như thế. Ý em nghĩ thế nào?
tr: Miss Bennet bir an duraksadıktan sonra cevap verdi, "Adamcağızı etrafa rezil etmen için bir sebep yok. Senin düşüncen ne?
es: Jane meditó un rato y luego dijo: ––Creo que no hay por qué ponerle en tan mal lugar. ¿Tú qué opinas?
vi_translation: Ms. Bennet hesitated for a moment, then replied: - There's certainly no chance to expose him in such a terrible way. What do you think?
tr_translation: After a moment's hesitation, Miss Bennet replied, "There is no reason to disgrace the poor man in front of everyone." "What is your opinion?""
es_translation: Jane meditated for a while and then said: ––I don't think there's any reason to put him in such a bad light. What do you think?

en: But as Elizabeth could not receive comfort from any such expectation she made no answer.
vi: Nhưng vì Elizabeth không cảm thấy an ủi về viễn cảnh như thế, nên cô không trả lời.
tr: Böyle bir beklentiden teselli bulamayan Elizabeth cevap vermedi.
es: Pero Elizabeth, que no podía consolarse con esas esperanzas se quedó callada.
vi_translation: But since Elizabeth did not feel comforted by such a prospect, she did not reply.
tr_translation: Elizabeth, unable to find solace in such an expectation, did not respond.
es_translation: But Elizabeth, who could not console herself with those hopes, remained silent.

en: “A great deal of good management, depend upon it. Yes, yes. They will take care not to outrun their income. They will never be distressed for money. Well, much good may it do them! And so, I suppose, they often talk of having Longbourn when your father is dead. They look upon it quite as their own, I dare say, whenever that happens.”
vi: - Việc quản lý phải thật khéo léo. Đúng, đúng vậy. Họ sẽ cẩn thận không tiêu pha quá lợi tức của họ. Họ sẽ chẳng bao giờ thiếu thốn tiền bạc. À, bao nhiêu điều tốt đẹp cho họ! Và như thế, mẹ đoán hai người thường nói đến việc chiếm lấy Longbourn khi bố con qua đời. Mẹ tin chắc họ xem nó như là của họ, một khi chuyện ấy xảy ra.
tr: "Çok idarelidir, çok, sözüme güven. Hakikaten. Kazandıkları kadar harcamaya dikkat ederler. O yüzden hiç para sıkıntısı çekmezler. Eh, Allah kabul etsin! Sonra, galiba, baban ölünce Longbourn'a konmaktan bahsederler sık sık. Kendi malları görüyorlar burayı, kanımca, önünde sonunda.
es: ––De ello depende la buena administración. Ya, ya; se cuidarán mucho de no derrochar su sueldo. Nunca tendrán apuros de dinero. ¡Que les aproveche! Y me figuro que hablarán a menudo de adquirir Longbourn cuando muera tu padre, y de que ya lo considerarán suyo en cuanto esto suceda.
vi_translation: - Management must be very skillful. Yes, that's right. They will be careful not to spend more than their income. They will never be short of money. Ah, so many good things for them! And so, I guess the two often talk about taking over Longbourn when your father passes away. I'm sure they consider it theirs once that happens.
tr_translation: "He is very frugal, very, trust my word. Truly. They are careful to spend only as much as they earn. That's why they never have money troubles. Well, may God accept it! Then, I think, they often talk about inheriting Longbourn when your father dies. They see this place as their own property, I suppose, eventually."
es_translation: ––Good administration depends on it. Yes, yes; they will be very careful not to squander their salary. They will never have money troubles. Good for them! And I imagine they often talk about acquiring Longbourn when your father dies, and that they already consider it theirs as soon as that happens.

en: “I am sure,” said she, “I cried for two days together when Colonel Miller’s regiment went away. I thought I should have broke my heart.”
vi: - Mẹ tin chắc mẹ sẽ khóc trong hai ngày với các con khi trung đoàn của Đại tá Millar ra đi. Mẹ nghĩ tim mẹ đã có thể tan nát. - Con tin chắc tim con sẽ tan nát.
tr: "İnanın," dedi, "Albay Millar'ın alayı gittiği zaman tam iki gün ağlamıştım. Öldüm bittim sanmıştım.
es: ––Recuerdo ––decía–– que lloré dos días seguidos cuando se fue el regimiento del coronel Miller, creí que se me iba a partir el corazón.
vi_translation: - I'm sure I will cry for two days with you when Colonel Millar's regiment leaves. I think my heart might break. - I am sure my heart will be broken.
tr_translation: "Believe me," she said, "when Colonel Millar's regiment left, I cried for exactly two days. I thought I was done for."
es_translation: ––I remember ––he said–– that I cried for two days straight when Colonel Miller's regiment left, I thought my heart was going to break.

en: With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry. It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them. She was confident of having performed her duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her disposition.
vi: Với câu trả lời này, Elizabeth buộc phải hài lòng, nhưng cô vẫn bảo lưu ý kiến của cô trong thất vọng và buồn nản. Tuy nhiên, cô không có tính bực bội mãi vì vương vấn với vụ việc. Cô mãn nguyện rằng đã làm tròn bổn phận của mình, và không có thiên tư cứ mãi bực dọc về những chuyện bất như ý, nhưng không thể trách được, để rồi thêm lo lắng.
tr: Bu cevapla Elizabeth avunmaya zorlanıyordu; ama kendi görüşü aynı kaldı ve babasının yanından hayal kırıklığına uğramış ve üzgün bir halde ayrıldı. Yine de, düşüne düşüne sıkıntılarını daha da artırma adeti yoktu. Vazifesini yaptığına emindi; kaçınılmaz felaketler için tasalanmak ya da endişeyle felaketleri büyütmek doğasında yoktu.
es: Elizabeth tuvo que contentarse con esta respuesta; pero su opinión seguía siendo la misma, y se separó de su padre pesarosa y decepcionada. Pero su carácter le impedía acrecentar sus sinsabores insistiendo en ellos. Creía que había cumplido con su deber y no estaba dispuesta a consumirse pensando en males inevitables o a aumentarlos con su ansiedad.
vi_translation: With this answer, Elizabeth was forced to be satisfied, but she still held onto her opinion in disappointment and frustration. However, she did not have the temperament to remain upset forever over the matter. She was content that she had fulfilled her duty, and did not have the tendency to stay upset over unpleasant matters, which were inevitable, and thus cause herself more worry.
tr_translation: Elizabeth was forced to find solace in this answer; but her own view remained the same, and she left her father's side feeling disappointed and sad. Nevertheless, she did not have the habit of increasing her troubles by dwelling on them. She was confident that she had done her duty; it was not in her nature to worry about inevitable disasters or to magnify them with anxiety.
es_translation: Elizabeth had to be content with this answer; but her opinion remained the same, and she parted from her father sorrowful and disappointed. But her character prevented her from increasing her troubles by dwelling on them. She believed she had fulfilled her duty and was not willing to consume herself thinking about inevitable evils or to increase them with her anxiety.

en: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her father’s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talents—talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
vi: Tuy nhiên, Elizabeth chưa từng làm ngơ những hành vi không phải phép của ông trên cương vị một người chồng. Cô luôn đau khổ khi nhìn thấy ông như thế, nhưng vì tôn trọng những khả năng của ông và vui vì được ông quý mến, cô cố gắng quên đi điều cô không thể bỏ qua, và gạt ra khỏi ý nghĩ những hành động đáng buồn khi ông tỏ ra thiếu trách nhiệm, hoặc thiếu tinh thần đoan trang lứa đôi khi ông phơi bày vợ ông trước sự khinh thường của con cái. Nhưng cô chưa từng bao giờ cảm nhận sâu sắc về những bất lợi của đám con gái trong một cuộc hôn nhân không hoà hợp như thế, cũng chưa từng nhìn ra những điều tệ hại trong việc sử dụng tài năng một cách lệch lạc – những tài năng nếu được khai thác đúng chỗ có thể ít nhất khiến các cô con gái được người khác tôn trọng, nếu không thể mở mang được đầu óc của bà vợ.
tr: Bununla beraber, Elizabeth babasının bir koca olarak davranışlarının uygunsuzluğuna karşı hiç kör olmamıştı. Bunları hep acı içinde seyretmişti; ama babasının yeteneklerine saygı duyduğu, ona gösterdiği sevgiye minnettar olduğu için, görmezden gelemediği şeyleri unutmaya, evlilik vazifesi ve adabının sürekli çiğnenmesinin, mesela karısını çocuklarının önünde her fırsatta küçük düşürmesinin son derece sevimsiz bir hareket olduğunu düşünmemeye çalışmıştı. Ama hiç şimdiki kadar güçlü hissetmemişti böyle uyumsuz bir evliliğin çocuklarının ne dertlere katlanmak zorunda olduklarını; hiç bu kadar iyi anlamamıştı yanlış hedeflere yönelmiş yeteneklerin ne kötülüklere yol açtığını –doğru kullanılsalar, o yetenekler hiç olmazsa kızlarının saygınlığını koruyabilirdi, karısının aklını geliştirmeyi beceremese bile.
es: Elizabeth, no obstante, nunca había dejado de reconocer la inconveniencia de la conducta de su padre como marido. Siempre la había observado con pena, pero respetaba su talento y le agradecía su cariño, por lo que procuraba olvidar lo que no podía ignorar y apartar de sus pensamientos su continua infracción de los deberes conyugales y del decoro que, por el hecho de exponer a su esposa al desprecio de sus propias hijas, era tan sumamente reprochable. Pero nunca había sentido como entonces los males que puede causar a los hijos un matrimonio mal avenido, ni nunca se había dado cuenta tan claramente de los peligros que entraña la dirección errada del talento, talento que, bien empleado, aunque no hubiese basta-do para aumentar la inteligencia de su mujer, habría podido, al menos, conservar la respetabilidad de las hijas.
vi_translation: However, Elizabeth had never ignored his improper behaviors as a husband. She was always distressed to see him like that, but out of respect for his abilities and happiness at being cherished by him, she tried to forget what she could not overlook and pushed out of her mind the sad actions when he showed irresponsibility or lacked the spirit of marital decorum by exposing his wife to the contempt of their children. But she had never deeply felt the disadvantages for the daughters in such a discordant marriage, nor had she ever recognized the harms of misusing talents – talents that, if properly harnessed, could at least earn the daughters respect from others, if not broaden the mind of their mother.
tr_translation: However, Elizabeth had never been blind to her father's inappropriate behavior as a husband. She had always watched these with pain; but because she respected her father's abilities and was grateful for the love he showed her, she tried not to think about the extremely unpleasant act of constantly violating the duties and decorum of marriage, such as belittling his wife at every opportunity in front of their children. But never had she felt so strongly the troubles that children of such an incompatible marriage had to endure; never had she understood so well the harm caused by talents directed at the wrong targets – talents that, if used correctly, could at least have preserved her daughters' dignity, even if they failed to improve her wife's mind.
es_translation: Elizabeth, nevertheless, had never ceased to recognize the impropriety of her father's conduct as a husband. She had always observed it with sorrow, but she respected his talent and was grateful for his affection, so she tried to forget what she could not ignore and to put out of her mind his continuous breach of marital duties and the decorum that, by exposing his wife to the contempt of her own daughters, was so exceedingly reprehensible. But she had never felt as she did then the harm that a discordant marriage can cause to the children, nor had she ever so clearly realized the dangers inherent in the misdirection of talent, talent that, if well employed, although it might not have been enough to enhance his wife's intelligence, could at least have preserved the respectability of the daughters.

en: Mrs. Gardiner abused her stupidity. “If it were merely a fine house richly furnished,” said she, “I should not care about it myself; but the grounds are delightful. They have some of the finest woods in the country.”
vi: Bà Gardiner chỉ trích sự dốt nát của cô: - Nếu chỉ có những ngôi nhà được trang trí cầu kỳ, mợ cũng không màng đi đến đấy; nhưng vùng đất này thật tuyệt. Nó có những khu rừng đẹp nhất nước.
tr: Mrs Gardiner ilgisizliğine kızdı. "Sadece zengin döşenmiş güzel bir ev olsaydı," dedi, "ben de umursamazdım; ama arazi harikulade. Civarın en güzel ormanlarından bazıları orada.
es: La señora Gardiner censuró su tontería. ––Si sólo se tratase de una casa ricamente amueblada ––dijo–– tampoco me interesaría a mí; pero la finca es una maravilla. Contiene uno de los más bellos bosques del país.
vi_translation: Mrs. Gardiner criticized her ignorance: - If there were only elaborately decorated houses, I wouldn't bother going there; but this land is truly wonderful. It has the most beautiful forests in the country.
tr_translation: Mrs. Gardiner was annoyed by the indifference. "If it were just a beautifully furnished house," she said, "I wouldn't care; but the land is magnificent. Some of the finest woods in the area are there."
es_translation: Mrs. Gardiner censured her foolishness. ––If it were just a richly furnished house ––he said–– I wouldn't be interested either; but the estate is a marvel. It contains one of the most beautiful forests in the country.

en: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike to the scheme.
vi: Theo cách ấy, vào buổi tối, cô hỏi người bồi phòng rằng dinh thự Pemberley là nơi nên thăm viếng hay không, ai là chủ nhân, và cô bình thản hỏi tiếp liệu chủ nhân đã đến đấy để vui hưởng mùa hè chưa. Người bồi phòng đáp rằng chưa. Bây giờ không còn gì để lo lắng, cô hiếu kỳ muốn đến xem ngôi nhà. Khi được hỏi ý kiến lần nữa vào sáng hôm sau, cô có ngay câu trả lời bình thản rằng thật ra cô không có gì phải phản đối ý định của hai ông bà.
tr: Buna göre, geceleyin odasına çekildiği zaman hizmetçiye Pemberley'nin güzel bir yer olup olmadığını, sahibinin kim olduğunu ve, epeyce tedirgin olarak, ailenin yazlıkta olup olmadığını sordu. Son soruya gayet sevindirici bir hayır cevabı geldi –tedirginliği bu şekilde geçince onun da evi görmek için büyük bir merak duyacak fırsatı oldu; ertesi sabah konu açılıp yine ona sorulduğunda cevabı hazırdı; gayet kayıtsız bir havayla plana itirazı olmadığını söyledi.
es: En consecuencia, al irse a descansar aquella noche preguntó a la camarera si Pemberley era un sitio muy bonito, cuál era el nombre de su dueño y por fin, con no poca preocupación, si la familia estaba pasando el verano allí. La negativa que siguió a esta última pregunta fue la más bien recibida del mundo. Desaparecida ya su inquietud, sintió gran curiosidad hasta por la misma casa, y cuando a la mañana siguiente se volvió a proponer el plan y le consultaron, respondió al instante, con evidente aire de indiferencia, que no le disgustaba la idea.
vi_translation: In that manner, in the evening, she asked the chambermaid whether the Pemberley estate was worth visiting, who the owner was, and she calmly inquired whether the owner had arrived to enjoy the summer yet. The chambermaid replied that he had not. Now with nothing to worry about, she was curious to see the house. When asked for her opinion again the next morning, she calmly replied that she actually had no objections to the couple's plan.
tr_translation: Accordingly, when she retired to her room at night, she asked the servant whether Pemberley was a beautiful place, who its owner was, and, quite anxiously, whether the family was at the summer house. The answer to the last question was a very reassuring no – with her anxiety thus relieved, she had the opportunity to feel a great curiosity to see the house; when the subject was brought up again the next morning and she was asked, her answer was ready; she said, with a very indifferent air, that she had no objection to the plan.
es_translation: Consequently, upon retiring that night, she asked the maid if Pemberley was a very beautiful place, what the name of its owner was, and finally, with no small amount of concern, if the family was spending the summer there. The negative response to this last question was the most welcome in the world. With her anxiety now gone, she felt great curiosity even about the house itself, and when the plan was proposed again the next morning and she was consulted, she instantly replied, with an evident air of indifference, that she did not dislike the idea.

en: They descended the hill, crossed the bridge, and drove to the door; and, while examining the nearer aspect of the house, all her apprehension of meeting its owner returned. She dreaded lest the chambermaid had been mistaken. On applying to see the place, they were admitted into the hall; and Elizabeth, as they waited for the housekeeper, had leisure to wonder at her being where she was.
vi: Họ đi xuống triền đồi, vượt qua một chiếc cầu và đánh xe đi vào cổng. Trong khi ngắm nhìn cận cảnh ngôi biệt thự, mọi lo lắng về việc sẽ gặp chủ nhân trở lại trong tâm trí cô. Cô lo ngại người bồi phòng kia có thể nhầm lẫn. Họ xin phép và được mời vào sảnh đường. Trong khi chờ đợi người quản gia, Elizabeth vẩn vơ nghĩ đến việc mình đã có mặt nơi đây.
tr: Yamaçtan aşağı indiler, köprüyü geçtiler, kapıya geldiler; Elizabeth evi daha yakından incelerken tekrar sahibiyle karşılaşma ihtimali aklına geldi. Hizmetçi yanılmış olmasın korkusuna kapıldı. Evi görmek için kapıyı çalınca hole alındılar; kahyanın gelmesini beklerlerken Elizabeth orada bulunuyor olmasına hayret etti.
es: Bajaron la colina, cruzaron un puente y siguieron hasta la puerta. Mientras examinaban el aspecto de la casa de cerca, Elizabeth temió otra vez encontrarse con el dueño. ¿Y si la camarera se hubiese equivocado? Después de pedir permiso para ver la mansión, les introdujeron en el vestíbulo. Mientras esperaban al ama de llaves, Elizabeth tuvo tiempo para maravillarse de encontrarse en semejante lugar.
vi_translation: They went down the hillside, crossed a bridge, and drove the carriage through the gate. While observing the mansion up close, all her worries about meeting the owner returned to her mind. She feared that the butler might be mistaken. They asked for permission and were invited into the hall. While waiting for the steward, Elizabeth idly thought about her presence there.
tr_translation: They went down the slope, crossed the bridge, and arrived at the door; while Elizabeth was examining the house more closely, the possibility of encountering its owner again crossed her mind. She was seized by the fear that the servant might have been mistaken. When they knocked on the door to see the house, they were taken into the hall; while waiting for the steward to come, Elizabeth was surprised to find herself there.
es_translation: They went down the hill, crossed a bridge, and continued to the door. While they examined the appearance of the house up close, Elizabeth again feared encountering the owner. What if the maid had been mistaken? After asking for permission to see the mansion, they were led into the vestibule. While they waited for the housekeeper, Elizabeth had time to marvel at finding herself in such a place.

en: “And that,” said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures, “is my master—and very like him. It was drawn at the same time as the other—about eight years ago.”
vi: Bà Reynolds chỉ một bức tiểu hoạ khác và nói: - Và đây là ông chủ của tôi, giống ông ấy lắm. Bức hoạ được vẽ cùng thời gian với bức kia, khoảng tám năm về trước.
tr: "Bu da," dedi Mrs Reynolds, başka bir minyatürü işaret ederek, "benim efendim –ona çok benziyor. Ötekiyle aynı zamanda çizildi –sekiz yıl kadar önce.
es: ––Y éste ––dijo la señora Reynolds indicando otra de las miniaturas–– es mi amo, y está muy parecido. Lo pintaron al mismo tiempo que el otro, hará unos ocho años.
vi_translation: Mrs. Reynolds pointed to another miniature painting and said: - And here is my boss, he looks a lot like him. The painting was made around the same time as the other one, about eight years ago.
tr_translation: "This one," said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another miniature, "is my master – it resembles him greatly. It was drawn at the same time as the other one – about eight years ago."
es_translation: ––And this one ––said Mrs. Reynolds, pointing to another of the miniatures–– is my master, and it is very similar. It was painted at the same time as the other one, about eight years ago.

en: Elizabeth coloured, and said, “A little.”
vi: Elizabeth đỏ mặt: - Tôi có quen biết chút ít.
tr: Elizabeth kızardı; "Bir parça," dedi.
es: Elizabeth se sonrojó y respondió: ––Un poco.
vi_translation: Elizabeth blushed: - I know a little bit.
tr_translation: Elizabeth blushed; "A little," she said.
es_translation: Elizabeth blushed and replied: ––A little.

en: “Not so much as I could wish, sir: but I dare say he may spend half his time here; and Miss Darcy is always down for the summer months.”
vi: - Không thường xuyên như tôi mong mỏi, thưa Ngài; nhưng tôi có thể nói phân nửa thời gian là ông ấy ở đây, còn cô Darcy luôn luôn đến ở đây trong mấy tháng hè.
tr: "İstediğim kadar çok değil, beyfendi; ama diyebilirim ki yılın yarısını burada geçirir; Miss Darcy de yaz aylarında hep buradadır.
es: ––No tanto como yo querría, señor; pero diría que pasa aquí la mitad del tiempo; la señorita Darcy siempre está aquí durante los meses de verano.
vi_translation: - Not as often as I would like, sir; but I can say that he is here half of the time, and Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months.
tr_translation: "Not as much as I would like, sir; but I can say that he spends half the year here; Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months."
es_translation: ––Not as much as I would like, sir; but I would say he spends half of his time here; Miss Darcy is always here during the summer months.

en: “His father was an excellent man,” said Mrs. Gardiner.
vi: Bà Gardiner nói: - Ông cụ là một người rất tốt.
tr: "Babası harika bir adamdı," dedi Mrs Gardiner.
es: ––Creo que su padre era una excelente persona ––agregó la señora Gardiner.
vi_translation: Mrs. Gardiner said: - The old man is a very good person.
tr_translation: "Her father was a wonderful man," said Mrs. Gardiner.
es_translation: ––I believe his father was an excellent person ––added Mrs. Gardiner.

en: “In what an amiable light does this place him!” thought Elizabeth.
vi: Elizabeth nghĩ: “Việc này khiến anh trở nên dễ thương làm sao!”
tr: "Bu sözler onu ne kadar da hoş gösteriyor!" diye düşündü Elizabeth.
es: «En qué buen lugar lo sitúa todo esto», pensó Elizabeth.
vi_translation: Elizabeth thought, "How endearing this makes him!"
tr_translation: "How charming these words make him appear!" thought Elizabeth.
es_translation: "What a good place this puts everything in," thought Elizabeth.

en: “He is certainly a good brother,” said Elizabeth, as she walked towards one of the windows.
vi: Elizabeth nói, khi cô bước đến một cửa sổ: - Ông ấy chắc chắn là một người anh tốt.
tr: "İyi bir ağabey olduğu belli," dedi Elizabeth, pencerelerden birine doğru yürürken.
es: ––Es realmente un buen hermano ––dijo Elizabeth dirigiéndose a una de las ventanas.
vi_translation: Elizabeth said, as she walked to a window: - He is definitely a good brother.
tr_translation: "It is clear that he is a good brother," said Elizabeth, walking towards one of the windows.
es_translation: ––He is really a good brother ––said Elizabeth, turning to one of the windows.

en: Elizabeth excused herself as well as she could: said that she had liked him better when they met in Kent than before, and that she had never seen him so pleasant as this morning.
vi: Elizabeth cố tự bào chữa; nói rằng cô mến anh khi họ gặp nhau tại Kent hơn là lúc trước; và rằng cô chưa từng thấy anh dễ chịu như sáng hôm nay.
tr: Elizabeth elinden geldiğince kendini mazur göstermeye çalıştı; Kent'te karşılaştıkları zaman öncekinden daha çok beğendiğini, hiç o sabahki kadar sevimli görmediğini söyledi.
es: Elizabeth se disculpó como pudo; dijo que al verse en Kent le había agradado más que antes y que nunca le había encontrado tan complaciente como aquella mañana.
vi_translation: Elizabeth tried to justify herself; she said that she liked him more when they met in Kent than before; and that she had never found him as pleasant as this morning.
tr_translation: Elizabeth tried her best to excuse herself; she said that she liked him more than before when they met in Kent, and that he had never seemed as charming as he did that morning.
es_translation: Elizabeth apologized as best she could; she said that upon seeing him in Kent, she had liked him more than before and had never found him as agreeable as that morning.

en: Elizabeth felt that they had entirely mistaken his character, but said nothing.
vi: Elizabeth nghĩ hai ông bà đã hoàn toàn nhầm lẫn về tư cách của anh, nhưng cô im lặng.
tr: Elizabeth karakteri hakkında tümüyle yanıldıklarını hissetti ama bir şey demedi.
es: Elizabeth se dio cuenta de que estaban completamente equivocados sobre su carácter, pero no dijo nada.
vi_translation: Elizabeth thought the couple were completely mistaken about his character, but she remained silent.
tr_translation: She felt that they were completely wrong about Elizabeth's character, but she said nothing.
es_translation: Elizabeth realized that they were completely wrong about her character, but she said nothing.

en: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and concerned: but as they were now approaching the scene of her former pleasures, every idea gave way to the charm of recollection; and she was too much engaged in pointing out to her husband all the interesting spots in its environs, to think of anything else. Fatigued as she had been by the morning’s walk, they had no sooner dined than she set off again in quest of her former acquaintance, and the evening was spent in the satisfactions of an intercourse renewed after many years’ discontinuance.
vi: Bà Gardiner cảm thấy ngạc nhiên và quan ngại, nhưng khi đi đến quang cảnh bà đã vui thú ngày xưa, mọi ý nghĩ đều nhường chỗ cho những hồi tưởng quyến rũ, và bà quá bận rộn chỉ trỏ cho ông chồng xem những điểm lý thú trong vùng nên không nghĩ đến điều gì khác. Mặc dù mệt mỏi vì chuyến đi bộ buổi sáng, sau khi an tối bà lại đi thăm những người quen cũ, bà hài lòng với những mối giao tình được nối lại sau nhiều năm đứt quãng.
tr: Mrs Gardiner şaşırdı ve endişelendi; ama o sırada eski güzel günlerinin mekânlarına yaklaştıkları için bu düşünceler yerlerini anıların cazibesine bıraktılar; civardaki ilginç yerleri kocasına işaret etmeye öylesine daldı ki başka bir şey düşünemedi. Sabah yürüyüşünden yorgun düştüğü halde, yemek biter bitmez tekrar eski tanıdıklarını aramaya girişti; akşam uzun bir ayrılıktan sonra tazelenen ilişkinin keyfi içinde geçti.
es: A la señora Gardiner le sorprendió y sintió curiosidad por el tema, pero como en aquel momento se acercaban al escenario de sus antiguos placeres, cedió al encanto de sus recuerdos y ya no hizo más que señalar a su marido todos los lugares interesantes y sus alrededores. A pesar de lo fatigada que estaba por el paseo de la mañana, en cuanto cenaron salieron en busca de antiguos conocidos, y la velada transcurrió con la satisfacción de las relaciones reanudadas después de muchos años de interrupción.
vi_translation: Mrs. Gardiner felt surprised and concerned, but when she arrived at the scene she had enjoyed in the past, all thoughts gave way to enchanting memories, and she was too busy pointing out interesting spots in the area to her husband to think of anything else. Although tired from the morning walk, after dinner she visited old acquaintances, and she was pleased with the relationships rekindled after many years of interruption.
tr_translation: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and worried; but as they approached the places of her old happy days, these thoughts gave way to the charm of memories; she became so engrossed in pointing out the interesting places in the vicinity to her husband that she couldn't think of anything else. Although she was tired from the morning walk, she immediately set out to search for old acquaintances as soon as the meal was over; the evening passed in the pleasure of a relationship renewed after a long separation.
es_translation: Mrs. Gardiner was surprised and curious about the topic, but as they were approaching the scene of her former pleasures, she yielded to the charm of her memories and only pointed out to her husband all the interesting places and their surroundings. Despite being tired from the morning walk, as soon as they had dinner, they went out in search of old acquaintances, and the evening passed with the satisfaction of relationships renewed after many years of interruption.

en: However little Mr. Darcy might have liked such an address, he contented himself with coolly replying, that he perceived no other alteration than her being rather tanned,—no miraculous consequence of travelling in the summer.
vi: Tuy anh Darcy có thể không thích lắm ngôn từ như thế, anh vẫn lạnh lùng trả lời rằng anh không thấy có thay đổi gì ngoại trừ nước da cô bị sạm nắng – đấy không phải là kết quả của phép lạ khi người ta du ngoạn trong mùa hè. Cô Bingley thêm:
tr: Mr Darcy böyle bir konuşmadan hoşlanmamış olsa da soğukça cevap vermekle yetindi: biraz bronzlaşmış olması dışında herhangi bir değişiklik görmemişti, –yazın seyahat edince de insanın bronzlaşması mucize sayılmazdı.
es: La observación le hizo a Darcy muy poca gracia, pero se contuvo y contestó fríamente que no le había notado más variación que la de estar tostada por el sol, cosa muy natural viajando en verano.
vi_translation: Although Mr. Darcy might not be very fond of such words, he still coldly replied that he saw no change except for her tanned skin – which was not the result of a miracle when one travels during the summer. Miss Bingley added:
tr_translation: Although Mr. Darcy did not like such a conversation, he contented himself with answering coldly: he had not seen any change except that she was a little tanned, –it was not a miracle for a person to get tanned when traveling in the summer.
es_translation: The remark amused Darcy very little, but he restrained himself and replied coldly that he had noticed no other change than being tanned by the sun, which was very natural when traveling in summer.

en: He then went away, and Miss Bingley was left to all the satisfaction of having forced him to say what gave no one any pain but herself.
vi: Rồi anh bỏ đi, để cô Bingley ngồi lại với niềm thoả mãn đã buộc anh phải mở miệng nói, nhưng anh nói ra điều chỉ làm cô đau đớn.
tr: Sonra çekip gitti, Miss Bingley de onu kendisinden başka hiç kimseye acı vermeyen bir şey söylemeye zorlamış olmanın tüm tatminiyle başbaşa kaldı.
es: Dicho esto, se fue y la señorita Bingley se quedó muy satisfecha de haberle obligado a decir lo que sólo a ella le dolía.
vi_translation: Then he walked away, leaving Miss Bingley sitting with the satisfaction of having forced him to speak, but what he said only caused her pain.
tr_translation: Then he left, and Miss Bingley was left with the full satisfaction of having forced him to say something that caused pain to no one but herself.
es_translation: Having said this, he left, and Miss Bingley was very pleased to have forced him to say what only hurt her.

en: Without allowing herself time for consideration, and scarcely knowing what she felt, Elizabeth, on finishing this letter, instantly seized the other, and opening it with the utmost impatience, read as follows: it had been written a day later than the conclusion of the first.
vi: Không cho phép mình có thời gian để suy nghĩ và không biết mình nghĩ gì, sau khi đọc xong lá thư thứ nhất, Elizabeth hấp tấp mở lá thứ hai ra đọc, được viết sau lá thư trước một ngày.
tr: Kendine düşünmek için zaman vermeden ve ne hissettiğini de bilmeden, Elizabeth bu mektubu bitirince hemen ötekine sarıldı; mektubu sabırsızlıkla açıp okudu: ilk mektuptan bir gün sonra yazılmıştı.
es: Sin tomar tiempo para meditar y sin saber apenas lo que sentía al acabar la lectura de esta carta, Elizabeth abrió la otra con impaciencia y leyó lo que sigue, escrito un día después:
vi_translation: Not allowing herself time to think and not knowing what she was thinking, after finishing the first letter, Elizabeth hastily opened the second letter to read, which was written one day after the previous letter.
tr_translation: Without giving herself time to think and without knowing what she felt, Elizabeth immediately grabbed the other letter as soon as she finished this one; she opened it impatiently and read: it was written one day after the first letter.
es_translation: Without taking time to reflect and barely knowing what she felt after finishing the reading of this letter, Elizabeth impatiently opened the other one and read the following, written a day later:

en: “Good God! what is the matter?” cried he, with more feeling than politeness; then recollecting himself, “I will not detain you a minute; but let me, or let the servant, go after Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are not well enough; you cannot go yourself.”
vi: - Chúa tôi! Có chuyện gì vậy? Rồi anh định tâm lại: - Tôi không muốn giữ cô lại phút nào, nhưng hãy cho phép tôi, hoặc để gia nhân đi tìm ông bà Gardiner. Cô không được khoẻ – cô không thể tự đi.
tr: "Aman Tanrım! mesele nedir?" diye haykırdı Darcy, kibarlıktan çok heyecan içinde; sonra kendini toparlayıp, "Sizi bir an bile tutmayacağım, ama bırakın ben arayayım onları, ya da uşak arasın. Siz iyi değilsiniz; kendi başınıza gidemezsiniz.
es: ––¡Dios mío! ¿De qué se trata? ––preguntó él con más sentimiento que cortesía; después, reponiéndose, dijo––: No quiero detenerla ni un minuto; pero permítame que sea yo el que vaya en busca de los señores Gardiner o mande a un criado. Usted no puede ir en esas condiciones.
vi_translation: - My God! What happened? Then he calmed himself down: - I do not wish to detain you for a moment, but please allow me, or let a servant go find Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner. You are not well – you cannot go by yourself.
tr_translation: "My God! What is the matter?" cried Darcy, more in excitement than politeness; then composing himself, "I won't keep you for even a moment, but let me call them, or let the servant call them. You are not well; you cannot go by yourself."
es_translation: ––My God! What is this about? ––he asked with more feeling than courtesy; then, recovering himself, he said––: I don't want to detain you for even a minute; but allow me to be the one to go in search of Mr. and Mrs. Gardiner or send a servant. You cannot go in those conditions.

en: Elizabeth hesitated; but her knees trembled under her, and she felt how little would be gained by her attempting to pursue them. Calling back the servant, therefore, she commissioned him, though in so breathless an accent as made her almost unintelligible, to fetch his master and mistress home instantly.
vi: Elizabeth do dự, nhưng hai đầu gối cô run rẩy, và cô nghĩ nếu cô tự đi sẽ bất lợi hơn. Cô gọi gia nhân lại, với giọng nói hổn hển hầu như không ai hiểu nổi, nhờ anh đi tìm hai ông bà lập tức.
tr: Elizabeth tereddüt etti, ama dizleri titriyordu ve peşlerinden gitmeye çalışmasının ne kadar faydasız olacağını hissetti. Bunun üzerine, uşağı geri çağırarak, soluksuzluktan neredeyse anlaşılmaz bir sesle efendisiyle hanımını derhal eve getirmesini söyledi.
es: Elizabeth dudó; pero le temblaban las rodillas y comprendió que no ganaría nada con tratar de alcanzarlos. Por consiguiente, llamó al criado y le encargó que trajera sin dilación a sus señores, aunque dio la orden con voz tan apagada que casi no se le oía.
vi_translation: Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees were trembling, and she thought it would be more disadvantageous if she went by herself. She called a servant over, with a breathless voice that was almost unintelligible, asking him to immediately find the couple.
tr_translation: Elizabeth hesitated, but her knees were trembling, and she felt how futile it would be to try to follow them. Upon this, she called back the servant and told him, in a voice almost unintelligible from breathlessness, to bring his master and mistress home immediately.
es_translation: Elizabeth hesitated; but her knees were trembling and she realized that she would gain nothing by trying to catch up with them. Consequently, she called the servant and instructed him to bring her masters without delay, although she gave the order in such a faint voice that she was barely heard.

en: She burst into tears as she alluded to it, and for a few minutes could not speak another word. Darcy, in wretched suspense, could only say something indistinctly of his
vi: Cô khóc nấc lên khi ám chỉ đến đấy, và trong vài phút không nói thêm được lời nào. Trong căng thẳng khốn khổ, Darcy chỉ có thể nói gì đấy không thông suốt về lòng quan ngại của anh, rồi im lặng nhìn cô trong thương cảm.
tr: Meseleye değinince gözyaşlarına boğuldu ve birkaç dakika boyunca tek kelime söyleyemedi. Tedirgin bir merak içindeki Darcy duyduğu endişeyi belli belirsizce dile getirebildi ve acıma dolu bir sessizlik içinde onu seyretti.
es: Al decir esto rompió a llorar y estuvo unos minutos sin poder hablar. Darcy, afligido y suspenso, no dijo más que algunas vaguedades sobre su interés por ella, y luego la observó en silencio.
vi_translation: She sobbed when she alluded to it, and for a few minutes couldn't say another word. In miserable tension, Darcy could only utter something incoherent about his concern, then silently watched her with compassion.
tr_translation: When she mentioned the issue, she burst into tears and couldn't say a word for several minutes. Darcy, filled with anxious curiosity, could barely express his concern and watched her in a silence full of pity.
es_translation: Upon saying this, she burst into tears and was unable to speak for a few minutes. Darcy, distressed and in suspense, said nothing more than a few vague remarks about his interest in her, and then watched her in silence.

en: Darcy was fixed in astonishment.
vi: Darcy đờ người vì sửng sốt.
tr: Darcy şaşkınlıktan olduğu yerde kalakalmıştı.
es: Darcy se quedó inmóvil de estupor.
vi_translation: Darcy was stunned into silence.
tr_translation: Darcy was frozen in place with astonishment.
es_translation: Darcy stood motionless in astonishment.

en: “I am grieved, indeed,” cried Darcy: “grieved—shocked. But is it certain, absolutely certain?”
vi: Darcy thốt lên: - Tôi lấy làm buồn, thật sự buồn… tôi bị sốc. Nhưng tin này có đúng không, có tuyệt đối đúng không?
tr: "Çok üzüldüm, gerçekten," diye haykırdı Darcy; "üzüldüm –şok oldum. Ama kesin miymiş?
es: ––Estoy horrorizado ––exclamó Darcy––. ¿Pero es cierto, absolutamente cierto?
vi_translation: Darcy exclaimed: - I am very sad, truly sad... I am shocked. But is this news correct, is it absolutely correct?
tr_translation: "I'm very sorry, truly," cried Darcy; "I'm sorry – I'm shocked. But is it certain?"
es_translation: ––I am horrified ––exclaimed Darcy––. But is it true, absolutely true?

en: “My father has gone to London, and Jane has written to beg my uncle’s immediate assistance, and we shall be off, I hope, in half an hour. But nothing can be done; I know very well that nothing can be done. How is such a man to be worked on? How are they even to be discovered? I have not the smallest hope. It is every way horrible!”
vi: - Bố tôi đã đi London. Jane viết thư xin cậu tôi giúp đỡ, riêng tôi hi vọng chúng tôi có thể lên đường trong vòng nửa giờ. Nhưng không thể làm gì cả, tôi biết rõ không thể làm được gì. Làm thế nào để tìm ra họ? Tôi không có hi vọng gì. Mọi chuyện đều quá khủng khiếp.
tr: "Babam Londra'ya gitmiş; Jane de mektup yazıp dayımın yardımını istedi; yarım saat içinde gideriz, umarım. Ama yapacak bir şey yok; biliyorum, yok. Böyle bir adam nasıl ikna edilir? Nasıl bulacağız onları? Hiç umudum yok. Her yanıyla korkunç!"
es: ––Mi padre ha ido a Londres y Jane escribe solicitando la inmediata ayuda de mi tío; espero que nos iremos dentro de media hora. Pero no se puede hacer nada, sé que no se puede hacer nada. ¿Cómo convencer a un hombre semejante? ¿Cómo descubrirles? No tengo la menor esperanza. Se mire como se mire es horrible.
vi_translation: - My father has gone to London. Jane wrote a letter asking my uncle for help, while I hoped we could set off within half an hour. But nothing could be done, I knew very well that nothing could be done. How to find them? I had no hope. Everything was too terrible.
